I have no recollection of how we got from that place to Bratislava COUNTRY .

But in Bratislava POPULATED_PLACE was a stop off place and I got very sick there .

I do n't know what I had .

I must have had the measles or something , but I was very ill and most of those children left except for one girl whom you saw I have a picture of .

I do n't know how long I was sick , but then other children started arriving and then we all were again a large enough group for us to continue and by small stages -- then I remember being on busses SPATIAL_OBJ , and they got us out from Czechoslovakia COUNTRY .

I think they probably must have gotten us through East REGION Germany and the West REGION Germany and then to France COUNTRY .

In France COUNTRY we ended up in a home BUILDING in Barbizon POPULATED_PLACE which is very close to Fountain POPULATED_PLACE Bleu .

It was a beautiful spot .

It was truly beautiful .

That 's where I got my first orange .

That 's where I got my first taste of chocolate , and that 's where they taught me to eat with a knife and fork -- not a knife , a fork .

We started with a fork .

I do n't think I ate with a knife for a while .

That 's where they started teaching us things .

We were like savages really .

That 's when I had my head shaved because I was full of life .

I was also ill , I was quite ill .

I could n't eat properly , you know .

My stomach would n't digest regular food .

I became very friendly -- it was so strange because the director of the camp was a man by the name of Eric Schott and he drove by and there was a group of us playing and he opened the door DLF and he motioned for me to come into the car SPATIAL_OBJ and he did .

And he took me to the home BUILDING where they lived which was on the grounds DLF , but it was very extensive grounds there , so he drove me to their home BUILDING and they gave me upstairs I met his wife and his son .

He had a son , and they gave me what you call in French , which is in the middle of the afternoon and they gave me little sandwiches with cheese and a piece of chocolate and some milk .

I thought that was absolutely delicious .

So , that was a wonderful place .

I have very good memories .

Once he asked me if I wanted to go and see what the sea ENV_FEATURES was like and I said sure .

I had n't seen the sea ENV_FEATURES in a long time .

I remembered it from the place NPIP we had , but he took his son and me to Brittany REGION for vacation for a whole week 's vacation and it was absolutely wonderful .

It was for the first time I started eating certain fish which I had never had and shrimp and things like that .

I had never tasted anything like it before .

That 's when I rejoined civilized life , really .

The older children in that group then left for Israel COUNTRY except for two , that little girl who stayed with me in Bratislava POPULATED_PLACE .

She found an aunt and uncle in Paris POPULATED_PLACE and she went to live with them , and I visited very often with them , and then when all the children had left , the director and his wife and their son moved to Paris POPULATED_PLACE and I moved with them .

That 's when I really started school BUILDING in earnest .

I had started school BUILDING already in Barbizon POPULATED_PLACE , but it was a one BUILDING room school with different grades .

When we moved to Paris POPULATED_PLACE , I really started regular school BUILDING and it was very hard at the beginning because I did n't speak the language yet and I had to learn to read and write at the age of 11 and the French are very strict where they place you .

So , they immediately decided that I had to go into a class with younger kids which was n't very good for my morale .

The first day that we had you know the spelling test , the teacher put my spelling on the board as an example of what not to do .

Twenty- three spelling mistakes , so I decided I had to learn fast , which I did , I did .

Esthy , when they kidnapped you , were you screaming ?

Did they talk to you ?

They were just holding me .

They said I had to come back .

I had to come back .

I belonged to the Jews and I had to come back amongst the Jews .

Oh , yes , I was screaming indeed .

I was fighting .

Did you decide I have no power here , I will just take what coming as you did all the other things ?

I had no choice .

I really had no choice .

Did you think about running away ?

Where was I going to run ?

Where would you run , you know , at that point .

If somebody fed you you stayed put because if you run who was going to feed you .

So , I was n't going to run because I did n't know exactly -- I could have never found my way back to the farm DLF , never .

I knew that .

I was not going to be caught .

I knew how violent the peasants can be , and I was n't going to be caught somewhere like that .

So , running away was n't an option really .

What point did you stop fighting or feel as if okay -- ?

Well , in Barbizon POPULATED_PLACE I sort of began to have a glimpse of another life .

When we went away to Brittany REGION which I found absolutely beautiful , I particularly liked i 1 remember .

I have pictures with their son from with Rene , who was the son of the Schotts .

And , I began to have a glimpse of another life and then when I started school BUILDING I very quickly learned how to read and write .

When you 're ready you learn it very quickly .

You do n't need several years like you have it here to learn how to read and write when you 're really of a certain age and you 're really motivated .

So , I learned how to read and write very quickly and I learned French very quickly and I started reading a lot and that opened up to me a whole new world once I started reading .

I knew now that maybe it was n't so bad what happened to me , and I absolutely loved France COUNTRY .

I found France COUNTRY beautiful .

Everywhere I looked -- the city of Paris POPULATED_PLACE I just could n't get enough .

I used to just wander around by myself everywhere and it was safe at the time to wander around anywhere you wanted in Paris POPULATED_PLACE .

I thought that that was the most glorious city POPULATED_PLACE that I had ever seen which it was .

I was pretty happy by then and I was adjusting very well , and I was learning lots of things .

I was going through school BUILDING .

I became very good at writing .

I was writing poetry in French .

I always found teachers who were always helpful and always pushing me along .

I enjoyed that .

It became very challenging to me and very stimulating not to disappoint them , you know , that the French are very big on competitions and regional tests and this and that , and I became a regular at the various competitions in writing and such because all of them wanted to send me because obviously I had a gift in that area REGION .

So , I began to really enjoy it .

I had to work very hard , because the French school system at the time was very difficult to get through .

It was very challenging and I had a lot of work to do and a lot of catching up to do .

It was ridiculous , I remember doing calculous and they discovered my multiplication table or my additions .

And we did n't have little calculators at the time and you really had to be able to calculate and I could n't .

So , somebody would always step in to coach me so I would have several weeks of coaching in addition to the regular school BUILDING .

They were sending me for competition in essays and they discovered that I did n't know the rules of grammar in French .

I had skipped the grade where there were rules of grammar so I had a tutor assigned to me from school BUILDING for a couple of weekends to teach me what the rules of grammar were .

You needed to know the rules of grammar when you off to a writing competition .

So , I was very busy and I was very caught up in that life , and I really enjoyed it very much .

You felt close to both Mr. and Mrs. Schotts ?

I felt very close to Mr. Schott .

Mrs. Schott , no .

Mrs. Schott was a bit of a basket case and a difficult woman , although I could n't blame her after she lost her son .

Honey died when he was --I was -- how old was I when he died ?

13 or 14 , and he must have been 17 years old and he died of cancer , a young boy .

So , that was a very terrible blow to them .

Were you close to him ?

I was very close to him , yes .

He was very protective of me , and I was delighted to have a big brother who was protective of me , so I felt very close to him .

I felt very close to Mr. Schott , in fact , I named my son after him .

My son is named Eric after Eric Schott .

And I got to know his family in England COUNTRY , and I became very close with his family .

He had a brother and a sister - in - law and a nephew who lived in England COUNTRY and I became very close to them .

In fact , I still see them .

Unfortunately he died , and his nephew died a couple years ago , but we spent some time before he died together because they were very important people in my life .

I made friends in Paris POPULATED_PLACE and I was doing lots of things .

So you put your life together ?

I really did .

Did you consider yourself a member of the Schott family ?

Up to the time when he died .

After that I did n't .

After that I had a whole series of places NPIP I lived .

She wanted to remarry and after all to have a young girl on her hands was not the best thing for her .

So , I went to live with a friend of theirs who was my tutor .

Eric Schott was my tutor first , and they appointed an assistant to him in case something happened to him , and when he died , I went to live with that other family by the name of Katts , and they were a terrible family to live with .

They really were .

Actually , I do n't think he particularly picked on me .

They had two sons and he was equally cruel to his two sons , so it was not a good place to live .

I stayed with them until I reached the age of 18 at which point in the French BUILDING court , you can be declared mature of age if two witnesses will testify to your character and your maturity , which is exactly what happened .

So , I became essentially 21 at the age of 18 .

From then on I could do as I pleased and I went to live with a family of two doctors who had been at that camp POPULATED_PLACE in Barbizon POPULATED_PLACE .

They were taking care of the children .

They were n't married , the two .

They lived together .

She had a little girl .

Her husband had been deported during the war and killed and I lived with them until I married Jim .

I met Jim in the summer of 1954 in Germany COUNTRY , as a matter of fact .

He was stationed at Heidelberg POPULATED_PLACE , and I was visiting with this family became they had gone back to live in Germany COUNTRY because he was a doctor and he could n't practice in France COUNTRY .

The French medical association is very reactionary and very tight and they would n't allow him to practice so , since he took his medical degree in Germany COUNTRY he went back to Mannheim POPULATED_PLACE where his family was a doctor and he opened up a very thriving practice , so she had to join him there and I lived with the daughter in Paris POPULATED_PLACE and during vacation time when we did n't have school BUILDING we would go to Mannheim POPULATED_PLACE and stay with them and then come back to Paris POPULATED_PLACE when school BUILDING resumed .

One of the trips in ' 54 I met Jim , who was in the United States Army , and I went back to France COUNTRY and he went back to the United COUNTRY States but two years later , he came back and we got married .

So , we were married in Paris POPULATED_PLACE .

You corresponded during this period ?

Not really .

Jim is not really a letter writing .

I know he can hear me .

Telegrams mostly .

He sent me telegrams , and also I must say my English was n't very good , so it was hard to correspond when your English is not very good .

So , did you take these people 's name ?

Lehman , yes , I took their name , that 's right .

So you were married -- ?

In Paris POPULATED_PLACE .

We were married in Paris POPULATED_PLACE , but then when we came here , his parents wanted a wedding too , so we had a second wedding for his parents , too .

And I did n't know anybody and it was very funny because whenever I was introduced to somebody and we would turn around to somebody else I would hear , is she Jewish ?

At one point I said to Jim why do n't you make a sign and put it on my back , I 'm Jewish .

Were you taught anything about Judaism after the war in Barbizon POPULATED_PLACE ?

Yes , as a matter of fact , I was in a very peculiar way .

You see , in order for me to catch up with the French school system I had to go into a private BUILDING school for a while to catch up .

And it so happened that I was sent one year to a very special private BUILDING school which was not Jewish and one year I was sent to a private BUILDING school which was Jewish , and the only way they would keep me there is if I would learn how to read and write Hebrew right away , which I did .

We had religious instruction and we read the Bible every day in addition to the regular curriculum , so I learned about Judaism there , as much as you can learn in a couple of years , you know .

I learned how to read and write .

I learned even how to read , which I can not do any more , but if I had to , I probably would again , I would learn it , if my future life depended on it , I would probably learn it again .

So , I did learn a little bit about Judaism .

It did n't take .

It really did n't take .

I think that the first time I really felt Jewish was after the Six Day War .

That 's when I really felt Jewish .

I do n't quite understand why except that maybe I saw the Jews stand up and fight and that did it forme .

They were defending themselves and they were defending their land , and for the first time I felt Jewish .

So , I feel perfectly Jewish now , but I did n't for a long time .

I really did n't .

What does that mean , do you think , feeling Jewish ?

Feeling that I 'm proud to be part of that breed .

Feeling that in spite of all the trials that we have gone through we are a very strong and resilient people , not feeling that I 'm ashamed of being a Jew .

That 's what it means essentially to me .

I ca n't say that I 'm really religious .

It 's just that I feel very Jewish .

I really do at this point .

I feel that I 'm part of this minority , and I 'm going to stay that way and I 'm going to tell my children about it and I hope my children stay part of the minority .

Is there a piece of the child in you feeling angry about what Jews did or did n't do during this period of time ?

I think , yes , there was a certain amount of anger in me .

There was the anger of our marching off like that .

I was very angry about the , but I have come to understand that we really did n't have a choice .

We were trapped and we really did n't have a choice .

But I did feel angry for a long time , you 're right .

And I think that 's probably why I did n't feel Jewish because I did n't want to be Jewish .

I was angry about it .

But the Sixth Day War showed me that if there was a way , the Jews can fight , you know , and they will fight .

That made a big difference to me really .

You 're identity is something that you 've created in a way that most people do n't .

Do n't most people create an identity for themselves ?

Yes , but you have a history that is lost to you .

That 's true .

Well , I had no choice really .

I had to create an identity .

You 're right .

I did create an identity for myself .

I did n't realize it was that unusual though .

I thought most people created their identities , no ?

But your history is one of so much oppression and so much terror as a child that you could n't be a child .

No , I guess I was always adult .

I guess I was always adult .

What was it like for you to raise children ?

It was n't easy .

You know the best way of understanding another person is to put yourself in their shoes and I am very good at putting myself in the shoes of adults .

I could n't put myself in the shoes of children .

As a consequence I was probably very over protective of my children .

I was always trying to keep them safe , which does n't work .

I have come to certainly realize that .

You ca n't keep anybody safe , but part of the reason was that I did n't remember what it was as a child .

I could n't venture out as a child because it was too dangerous , so consequently I probably tried to keep my children from straying somewhere where there might be danger .

And I know that I had peculiar fears like if they had a rash it used to drive me crazy until I realized that it had to do with that little girl that that was shot because she had pimples .

I associated pimples always with being sick and if you 're sick you 're going to get shot .

So , my kids never had a rash I can tell you that .

I drove them crazy but they did n't have a rash .

You know , it 's things like that that I probably overdid as a mother .

But for a long time my children did n't know my past , which is again , I 'm told , I did n't realize but I 'm told that this is not usual with survivors of the Holocaust .

I remember the first time my daughter came back from religious BUILDING school and they were talking about the Holocaust and she asked me point blank are you a Holocaust survivor , and I said yes , and she got very upset .

By then I think she must have been 10 or 11 years old which is an advanced age and she never had a glimmer that I might be a Holocaust survivor .

So , you know , it 's -- .

Did you then tell her ?

Some , but then I was n't able to talk about it all so I was very reticent and that probably created more anxiety than if I had told her .

Our son never questioned me about it .

He 's the kind of a child probably that I was .

He absorbed things by observing .

He does n't ask that many questions so he just absorbed and watched and did n't ask too many questions .

My daughter is a real questioner .

She likes to ask questions .

Some of the answers I gave were n't entirely satisfactory .

Part of the reason was I was n't able to talk about it then , yet .

It did n't come until much later when I was able to talk about it .

I just sort of decided this was my past life , another life .

I was living in a different life and I was going to pretend I 'm just as normal as everybody else .

So , that 's really the mission I took on .

I was going to lead a normal life .

Did you imitate other mothers that you saw ?

And also , I had an instinct .

I have a protective instinct to begin with so I would never do any harm to a child , so I 'm very protective of children .

So , that 's -- and I read so I understood some of the things that were going on , and I did let go of the children , I must say .

Maybe not as fast or as soon as they wanted it to happen , but it happened .

No , I understood suffering so I was always trying to nurture and avoid suffering , but I suppose that I must have brought certain hang ups with me that other mother 's did n't have , I suppose .

Maybe we should bring the pictures over here .

Why do n't you explain .

This picture was taken , it does n't show my finger , is that okay ?

This picture was taken in Bratislava POPULATED_PLACE in 1946 , and I am the girl in the middle next to the white bunny and the little boy who leans on my right arm we call him the Englishman because nobody could understand what language he was talking , which he spoke in .

We all had a smattering of different languages , but nobody understood his .

So , that was the Englishman leaning on me .

So you 're second to the left there in the first row ?

I 'm second to the left .

Do you remember the other people ?

No , I just do n't remember them , except for that little boy .

He was always next to me .

He was always leaning against me , but he did n't speak .

He never spoke .

I never heard him speak .

This picture also was taken in Bratislava POPULATED_PLACE and that 's the whole group .

You can see it 's a pretty large group .

Where are you ?

There I go .

That 's the one , that 's me .

Around time , that was taken around the same time I would say .

Same hat , same coat , I did n't have any more than that .

Maybe somebody who knows Czechoslovakia COUNTRY will recognize the monuments , but I do n't remember it .

I know it was Czechoslovakia COUNTRY , and I think it was Bratislava POPULATED_PLACE , although we were also in Prague POPULATED_PLACE , but I think it was Bratislava POPULATED_PLACE .

This picture I 'm the one holding on to two hands .

So you 're this person ?

That 's me , that was taken later .

That was taken in France COUNTRY .

By then you can tell my hair had grown back a little bit .

I had my head shaved when I came to France COUNTRY and by then it was growing back a little bit .

I forgot to tell you a story .

Mrs. Roosevelt came to visit the home BUILDING and I was designated to learn by heart The Raven and to recite The Raven to her , which I did .

When I was finished she patted me on the head and said , " What a cute little boy . "

So that was my first meeting with Mrs. Roosevelt .

I met Mrs. Roosevelt later on because my husband and I started a Reformed Democratic Club when we lived in New POPULATED_PLACE York and she came to be our speaker and Jim and I went to pick her up .

I told her the story when I first met her and she looked at me and said , " My you have changed . "

So , those were my encounters with Mrs. Roosevelt .

Thank you so much Esthy .

Could you tell me your name please ?

Niels Bamberger .

And where and when were you born ?

I was born in October 1928 in Germany COUNTRY .

Wurzburg POPULATED_PLACE , Germany COUNTRY .

And I was born , as an infant , my parents fled Germany COUNTRY to Copenhagen POPULATED_PLACE 1n 1932 , where my mother originally had come from .

And , uh , she lived in ... 1n Germany COUNTRY for nine years , ten years .

Then she went back to Denmark COUNTRY .

Why had she lived in Germany COUNTRY for ten years ?

Because she got married .

She grew up in Denmark COUNTRY and lived in Denmark COUNTRY and then she married my father who lived in Germany COUNTRY and they were married in 1923 and then they went back to Denmark COUNTRY when it started to get ... uh ... with Hitler , and it started to get too hot in Germany COUNTRY .

Then they went back to Denmark COUNTRY .

And that 's where I actually grew up and lived half of my life .

Okay .

Tell me about ... what did your father do ?

What was his occupation ?

Well , in Denmark COUNTRY he had an antique BUILDING store .

He had an art BUILDING store ; and they started that like in 1935 - 36 in Copenhagen POPULATED_PLACE , ' til we fled to Sweden COUNTRY in 1943 .

Tell me if you would about growing up in Copenhagen POPULATED_PLACE before the Germans came , in the ' 30s ?

I went to a non BUILDING - Jewish school BUILDING .

I was ... I would n't say I was the only Jew in school BUILDING , but we were probably two or three fellows and the school BUILDING was from 8 to 2 every day and then in the afternoon , we went for Hebrew ... for Hebrew lessons or Hebrew BUILDING school for another two , three hours .

So we came back ... we came home BUILDING like 5:30 , 6:00 every night and did our homework .

And that was the same routine .

Of course , we had no schools Saturday or Sunday .

Then we were off and we went to football games and bicycling and things like that .

Whatever we did with my friends .

What was your ... your parents BUILDING ' home BUILDING like .

Did you practice ... ?

Well , we had a house BUILDING in Copenhagen POPULATED_PLACE , in the center REGION of Copenhagen .

We had our own house BUILDING that had belonged to my grandfather and great grandfather .

It 's still standing there now .

And it 's probably two or three hundred years old .

And we had a big apartment INT_SPACE on the second INT_SPACE floor .

There were other people living in the house BUILDING and then there were stores BUILDING .

There were stores BUILDING on the ground INT_SPACE floor .

And we had a synagogue BUILDING that had been there for more than one hundred years also started by my great - grandfather on ... in the same house BUILDING we had that .

In the same house BUILDING ?

And it 's still there .

It 's not anymore there today because it was given to the city of Copenhagen POPULATED_PLACE .

Tell me how that worked ?

That is were you ... you must have been heavily ... your family was heavily involved in that synagogue BUILDING ?

We were very ... I was brought up very Orthodox ; and , of course , my parents were too .

My grandfather was a Rabbi , and my brother is a Rabbi today .

So that 's the way we grew up .

We ... we had a very good life .

Like Tove said .

And uh ... we had no problems whatsoever all the time .

Not money - wise or economic or we had no problem until it started in October ' 43 , and the Germans had been in the country for three years from ' 40 to ' 43 .

Hold it for one minute .

Before we get to the Germans , I would like to know a little more about your being Jewish in Copenhagen POPULATED_PLACE .

And you were so closely involved in the synagogue BUILDING .

What ... what did your Jewish life consist of ?

What kinds of things did you do ?

Holidays , services , what ?

We had services every day in our synagogue BUILDING .

And , of course , we had the sabbath , the Jewish Sabbath every week , and we had the Jewish holidays .

And uh ... the reason our synagogue BUILDING was started originally of ... by my great grandfather or grandfather was that he did n't think that the big synagogue BUILDING -- they have a beautiful , large synagogue BUILDING in Copenhagen-- POPULATED_PLACE but that was n't Orthodox enough hundred years ago .

They started with , uh ... different reformed things ; and they cut this prayer out and they cut this one out .

And that 's when my grandfather started his own synagogue BUILDING , so to speak .

And like I said , it still ... it still can be seen .

It 's in the museum BUILDING in Copenhagen POPULATED_PLACE ... the city POPULATED_PLACE .

You see them in Copenhagen POPULATED_PLACE .

They have ... they removed everything when the house BUILDING was sold a couple of years ago .

It ... like I said , it 's a very old building BUILDING , and it 's in the heart of the city POPULATED_PLACE .

And there was no money to pay the taxes and the roof DLF was falling apart so to speak and ... uh ... then it was sold .

The house BUILDING was sold , and the synagogue BUILDING was removed .

And that 's the story .

Today , it 's just an old , uh ... landmark building BUILDING in the center of Copenhagen POPULATED_PLACE that 's being owned by a private man or corporation .

I do n't know who has it today .

Uh , in growing up in such a very ... in a Orthodox Jewish home , did you feel differently ?

Did you feel you were treated differently than your Christian neighbors ?

Not at all .

They were my friends .

And , uh ... we went together for this or for that and we had birthday parties and we went to ball games and things like that , I said before .

And , uh ... there was no difference .

Nobody ever mentioned anything about Jewish or non - Jewish .

We were all the same .

We were citizens of Denmark COUNTRY and that 's all they cared about .

Nobody said you are Jewish or you are not Jewish .

That made no difference to us .

When the Germans invaded in 1940 , you would have been 12 years old ?

Right .

Uh , what can you tell me about , uh ... the invasion itself ?

Well , we know that , uh , there were soldiers all over .

And they threw out leaflets all over the city POPULATED_PLACE , all over the country COUNTRY that people could just go now and do n't make any uproar .

Everything will continue the way it was .

Of course , everything became rationed or rationed whatever .

And ... uh ... we were in school BUILDING that day .

We saw loads and loads of planes SPATIAL_OBJ , bombing planes SPATIAL_OBJ coming one after ... I mean hundreds and hundreds of planes SPATIAL_OBJ coming in and Germans on motorcycles SPATIAL_OBJ , horses , dragging cannons and the big tanks SPATIAL_OBJ all over the place NPIP .

It did n't take more than a couple of hours ‘ til they took over the country .

Like I said they [ the Danes ] could n't resist .

Denmark POPULATED_PLACE was a very small country .

And , uh ... life went on as before , except that that you are not allowed to walk on this side of the street DLF in front of the bank BUILDING .

They would post soldiers with , uh ... guns and ... and steel helmets and things like that in front of the banks BUILDING and the hotels BUILDING and important institutions that they wanted to guard .

But besides that nothing happened really .

The police was in force and the Danish Army was ... although they were there , they had not much to say or to do , but they were all ... life was continuing the way it was .

Everything got rationed and we had to buy butter and bread and gasoline , all the things .

You could n't go out and buy whatever you wanted , but there was plenty of it around .

The Germans took away whatever they needed , but there was still plenty .

Denmark COUNTRY is a dairy country , so there was plenty of food for everybody .

And then in ... uh ... 1 in 1943 , they took the ... they arrested all the police and the Army .

They took them away in August of ' 43 .

That 's when we know ... knew something was going to happen .

They took them away and interned them all in camps POPULATED_PLACE and took their weapons away and then they said that 1 t was the police 's fault and the army .

Then all of a sudden they switched over and they said that it 's all the Jews ' fault .

I mean they did n't say it , but we knew that something was going to happen .

How ?

Tell me what your life had been like in those three years and then we will continue .

The same thing like before .

We went to school BUILDING .

We had food .

We had all holidays .

Will you start by telling me your name , date of birth , and where you were born please ?

My name Sol Fox .

Now it 's Sol Fox .

It was in Polish , where we lived before , Shlomick Fuchs .

I was born September 2 , 1922 in Lodz POPULATED_PLACE , Poland COUNTRY to a very , very well to do family .

We were seven children .

We were seven children , one sister and six brothers .

I was amongst the two youngest .

The distance between me and my next brother was four years .

Therefore they already were involved in the family business , while I and my younger brother were going to this very famous high BUILDING school .

If I might explain at this moment , what it meant to get a high school education where we come from .

In this country it 's compulsory to have a high school education .

Where we come from in Poland COUNTRY , only seven classes of basic BUILDING school , you call it Public BUILDING school , was compulsory .

High School was either private or they also had governmental subsidized , taxpayers subsidized high schools .

Those accepted only two percent of a small percentage of Jewish students , and they had to be the best .

Therefore , to afford to go to high BUILDING school , you had to had support of a family that could afford it .

It was expensive .

Almost all in my family did have education at high school education and me and my younger brother who went together , that was a big expense for my parents .

In this way , I 'm paying homage to my parents .

A very bright future was in sight that my father , should he rest in peace , planned particularly for me .

Not that I 'm trying to point myself out that I was an exceptional son , which was not true at all , because my younger brother was the darling of the house BUILDING .

He was much smarter and better student , but my father had planned at least one of his sons to become an angromomist and go to Israel COUNTRY .

That was supposed to be me .

So , by that I 'm trying to stress the fact how this Holocaust business broke lives from the Shoresh , in Hebrew it means from the root .

I am glad I injected a Hebrew word .

So , we had a normal , beautiful , very beautiful life .

My parents , as I say , were well to do people .

I might add at this point that my mother and my grandfather , I come from a religious BUILDING home .

My father was dressed religiously , not any more the children .

We started to get modernized .

But my grandfather even owned his own synagogue BUILDING .

The synagogue BUILDING that we were praying in , it was like a private synagogue BUILDING .

I 'm not talking about a big building synagogue BUILDING .

It was like in his private BUILDING home .

He was a wealthy man , and he owned the building BUILDING , so he allowed one room INT_SPACE for prayers only on Saturdays .

Himself , my parents , were going for like you go here to Sarasota POPULATED_PLACE , you know , to baths INT_SPACE , will that be explainable ?

To Germany COUNTRY , Marienbad POPULATED_PLACE , Francisbad POPULATED_PLACE , Karlsbad POPULATED_PLACE , and when they came back they had the biggest praise .

They were doing that for many years before Hitler , before Nazism .

So , when this thing came on us , the shock was yet bigger , because my parents and my grandfather , and anybody who ever had contact with the German people , could n't understand what happened .

How could they turn into , and I must say it , and I promised myself on one of the notes , I would not be sarcastic and I will not be insulting to Germany COUNTRY as it 1s , not as I knew before .

I do n't know how they are now .

I really do n't .

But , how could they have changed into --- oh , oh , see I lost my thought .

Sometimes we say when somebody is bad you say he 's vicious .

He 's worse than an animal .

Whenever I get to this point , I say I can not insult the kingdom of animals .

I hate to see it , but it really comes out of me .

Those Germans , if I would put it at the mildest , not wanted to insult today 's Germans , though in doing me a lot of harm already for the last 50 years .

I was in Germany COUNTRY only six months .

I do n't want to insult the kingdom of animals , because they were definitely absolutely worse .

You can not imagine how vicious they were .

You can not imagine the devotion that they had to that Fuehrer .

Because I learned German in school BUILDING , too .

We learned Hebrew , German , Polish and Latin in our high BUILDING school .

It was multi - language .

Polish was the main language .

Hebrew was second , German was third .

My German teacher was a lady who came from a very religious , Jewish BUILDING home in our city POPULATED_PLACE of Lodz POPULATED_PLACE , Schneiersohn .

Everybody knew the religious family of Schneiersohn .

There was nothing wrong with the Schneiersohns to have a daughter speaking and teaching German to students with the deepest German dialect .

So , when I have to say it , I know how to and it happened in Court .

I had an incident when I said it in deep German and I 'll maybe explain later what it was .

The way the whole thing done in the most murderous , vicious , sadistic , as my teacher said , that he could n't find words in the world 's lexicons , dictionaries to express the viciousness and the pain of the Holocaust experience .

I went through high BUILDING school .

Our system had four classes and two which was called Lyceum .

I made it through the first of Lyceum because the Germans invaded on Friday morning , 5:00 , 1939 , September 1 .

On September 2 , as you remember I was born on September 2 , was my birthday , my 17th birthday .

We did not yet realize the scope of the tragedy even if Nazism in Germany COUNTRY started in ' 33 or even before .

We heard things , even if the media was not as developed as today , but we knew , because it was only a border DLF away .

So , when it came , we knew that a tragedy was coming .

We did n't even use the word tragedy .

We knew tough times were coming .

Bad people are coming .

The Germans are hurting us , even killing some , but little did we realize the scope of it .

To get as I am saying , to try and tell it is to do injustice to it .

It 's impossible .

Let me try to give you some small instances .

My sister was married a year before the war , therefore her baby was born the 26th of August one week before the war .

Being that my parents were able to afford , and she married also a very well to do husband , they got an apartment INT_SPACE for her in a very fine neighborhood POPULATED_PLACE , and it was equipped to the tee .

Why not ?

She was the only daughter .

Q. Was this a Jewish POPULATED_PLACE neighborhood ?

A. This was not the very Jewish POPULATED_PLACE neighborhood where she moved to .

She moved sort of like to the City POPULATED_PLACE .

There were Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE neighborhood , what we called Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE neighborhood .

I lived ina Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE neighborhood .

I was born there .

This was the center of Jewish life in the city POPULATED_PLACE .

Then came the business REGION section where we had our business , and my sister lived further down .

It was a mixed neighborhood POPULATED_PLACE .

As a matter of fact , it was diagonally across from my wife 's high BUILDING school .

But then we did n't realize it .

But , I 'm aiming at something .

The name , the landlords of that building BUILDING , were German .

The population of our city POPULATED_PLACE had a lot of Jews , Germans , and Poles .

The population was about 900,000 of which 30 percent was Jewish and a lot of Germans .

Now , these neighbors were Germans , the Richter family .

Very wealthy in the steel industry .

As soon as the Germans arrived and we noticed how bad it got and everybody started running in all directions , my father , my parents -- we were still intact , brought my sister and her baby to our house BUILDING .

That she should n't be alone there , because her husband had to go to attend to his problems .

Everybody had problems .

When she came back to the apartment INT_SPACE , it was empty .

Mrs. Richter , the millionaire German landlady , emptied my sister 's apartment INT_SPACE , because it was all new .

She was just married .

I was chosen by my father because I learned German in school BUILDING , so he helped himself with me rather than with the other children and not with my younger brother .

You see my younger brother 's picture there in the back ?

Because he was still too young .

I was already like a man , and I knew the language .

He says go ask Mr. Richter what happened .

So , I went .

I knocked at the door DLF .

It was one flight up , left door DLF , and she opened the door DLF and I said Frau Richter , " Wer hat meiner Schwester Moebel ' rausgenommen ? "

Sie sind doch tod " she said to me . "

I was yesterday at the party meeting . "

How did I know that she belongs to the party . "

We were told that you were all dead .

We had three stores BUILDING , retail BUILDING stores , besides wholesale shoes .

But to come to the story of how fast they liquidated our businesses BUILDING .

All the others were pushed in here , and we had to share the apartment INT_SPACE with everybody .

Where we lived , as I said before , was the Jewish POPULATED_PLACE neighborhood where the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE was then formed eventually .

This was the first real shock that went through me .

I was shocked .

Because the next shock did n't take very long when they confiscated completely our business .

Can you imagine anything like that .

Why do you need furniture so I took it out " .

On the main street DLF like here you would say Fifth DLF Avenue or 14th DLF Street , call 1 t anything you want , but the main business POPULATED_PLACE section .

They drove up with trucks SPATIAL_OBJ .

Asked no questions .

Broke in the doors DLF , emptied everything and took it away .

But they left a receipt with an address where to come for payment , but the way the whole thing was done was already scary besides we knew what 's going on in Germany COUNTRY .

Q. When was this ?

A. ' 39 , immediately .

Q. In September , right away ?

A. A week , two weeks later .

Immediately .

So , again , my father turned to me .

Who would go ?

As I told you before my father was 01:14 :)) Jewishly dressed .

Had the beard and pyes , like a religious man .

Naturally , he would n't go .

He would n't send boys because we figured boys is more dangerous .

But we still underestimated -- rather overestimated the German character figuring that if a woman will go , they would n't beat them or do anything wrong to a woman .

Men , it 's more dangerous .

So , it was decided that mother went .

It was already curfew .

5:00 was curfew .

Mother went with this receipt to the place NPIP where they were told to come , and curfew time came closer and mother did n't come back .

She 's not here .

You know we 're in trouble .

We realized we 're in trouble and started being very , very nervous about it , and again come close to curfew , Father chose me and says go there .

We knew the address where she went .

See where Mother is .

There 's not question that you went .

I went there .

We still did n't know the score that it was dangerous even to make a step on the street DLF .

I went there , into the animal 's mouth , you know , into an office INT_SPACE where my mother was already in jaihl BUILDING .

I came there it was already dark .

It was getting dark .

So , the lights were on in these offices BUILDING , and I just started walking around .

I could have been squeezed to death or shot to death or killed or taken right away .

They did n't probably realize who I am immediately .

I did n't see mother .

Now , imagine that I came back without mother , because curfew was over , I was still able to take a tram SPATIAL_OBJ .

Still able to grab on and get home BUILDING a little past curfew .

We did n't know that you could have gotten killed for being out on curfew , but I come without Mother .

We never seen her .

That 's when we escaped to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

After a few days or weeks , I do n't remember exactly , Father decided because Litzmannstadt POPULATED_PLACE , Lodz POPULATED_PLACE was turned into the name Litzmannstadt POPULATED_PLACE and it was getting terrorized .

The city POPULATED_PLACE was getting terrorized more and more every minute and we realized that being that they already have mother in , they 'll lead to us .

Meaning , mainly we talk of Father .

The decision was that my father and his sons , all of my brothers , and my sister and her baby are escaping to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE , which was only supposed to be only occupied territory .

Not incorporated in the REGION Reich , not the Holy POPULATED_PLACE Land .

Q. Let me ask you a question .

When you say the City POPULATED_PLACE was becoming more terrorized , what was happening on the streets DLF ?

A. That 's a good question .

The Germans came in shortly before - that 's a good question -- shortly before Rosh Hoshana .

The Jewish New Year .

Before the war started , already feeling that it was coming , we were digging on order of the government , we had to dig shelters DLF in the street DLF against bomb attacks .

Let me say something , yet better .

Before they came in , big announcements were hung out , what do you call these announcements on walls DLF ?

Q. Posters ?

A. Yes , yes .

That it is not true the rumors that you 're hearing about the atrocities about the German Army and the Germans is not true .

Come out when you see the German Army when they come marching in , and greet them .

You hear that ?

And everything was going fine and smooth .

We have seen an Army that we did n't even imagine exists because the Polish Army was a thousand years behind with little horse and buggies SPATIAL_OBJ .

Here at once you see a motorized , not one horse , everything in tanks SPATIAL_OBJ and on trucks SPATIAL_OBJ .

We went out in the main street DLF and nothing happened .

That lasted only a day or two .

Then they started grabbing Jews and burying them in the shelters BUILDING .

Q. They shot the Jews ?

A. No , they did n't need to shoot you .

If he wanted , he could shoot you .

They did n't make a big tsimmes , a big deal about how you died .

They wanted you to die the most miserable way .

So , throwing you into a mass BUILDING shelter like that and covering you up , to them that was a very befitting way to doing it to Jews .

Anyway , we decided to escape to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

Escaping to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

How do you escape to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE ?

Do you buy a ticket on the plane SPATIAL_OBJ or on the train SPATIAL_OBJ .

Do you take your car SPATIAL_OBJ from the garage BUILDING ?

There was no such thing .

Number one , we were immediately forbidden to use public transportation .

Anyway , it was still the beginning and there was still some horse and buggies SPATIAL_OBJ and imagine when I think of it now , that by horse and buggy SPATIAL_OBJ and the winter got tough , like in spite , very cold and a baby also with us , and we made it finally to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

It 's easier said than done .

So , now to describe the terror that happened in these few weeks is as impossible as to describe the whole thing , because when you 're talking about terror , is not only that something happened .

Say , somebody gets killed by a car SPATIAL_OBJ .

Somebody gets killed by a brick falling down .

That 's a tragedy , but that 's not terror .

That 's why I do n't call myself a survivor and I already was talking with our organization .

I 'm not big mixer , I do n't push .

We 're not survivors , we are victims .

Because a survivor is one who gets hurt by any means and then he gets revived and if the other person or realtor has any type of insurance which they do , they will be made good for .

They 'll take him to a hospital BUILDING , and if he 's lucky he 'll come back as a survived person .

We are not survivers .

We suffered day and night .

Because why did my wife have to have a dream fifty years later that they take the children and it 's cold outside NPIP and they do n't have socks on .

This is not one occasion .

If it 's a funeral , a bar mitzvah , a wedding , a card game a restaurant BUILDING and we were this week twice , that this thing does not come up amongst us .

I do n't know if you did realize it .

This is why my neighbor Mary once said to me , " Sol , why do n't you start living a normal life ?

Get it out of your mind . "

Easy said .

Get it out of your mind .

I wish it could .

There is not a day , if more than once a day , if we go to sleep , if we go to eat , if we meet for a game , if we go for a walk , always comes up .

This was -- it can not be told .

It can not be told .

As my teacher said , he can not find expression in the dictionaries of the languages .

You can see that we can go on and on forever .

If you need to go home BUILDING to sleep , you will not .

So , ask me questions which will lead me in , otherwise I get lost in it .

Q. You made your way to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

Did you go directly there ?

A. Oh , you got me back on track .

So , we made our way to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

Father , six of his sons , no , five of his sons .

One of our brothers died before the war .

Five sons , his only grandchild which was the light in his eye .

She was only a few weeks old , our first grandchild .

My brother- in - law did not come along because he had a big business to take care of .

He was a big businessman .

I 'll tell you how he died .

He was thrown out of a hospital DLF BUILDING window by the Germans .

We will get to that .

Now , we are in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

Q. You went directly there ?

You did n't stay -- ?

A. You do n't go so directly by horse and buggy SPATIAL_OBJ to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE , you know .

We stopped over in different places NPIP to sleep over and we slept on the street DLF and we slept in Konushki POPULATED_PLACE ( ? )

on city POPULATED_PLACE not so far .

The rabbi of Konushki POPULATED_PLACE ( ? ) ,

his son rather , opened his house BUILDING for the escapees , and we slept on the floor INT_SPACE , masses of us .

When I say we made it to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE , it was n't the same day .

The locomotives SPATIAL_OBJ did n't say , hey we 're in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

No , so , we got to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE , now we are homeless .

A whole homeless family .

There were no brokers or realtors to contact before or anybody provide me a roof DLF over my head .

But somehow , Father had plenty of money , he got an apartment INT_SPACE .

It happened to be by coincidence the apartment INT_SPACE was placed right across the street DLF from the so called Pawiak BUILDING .

Pawiak BUILDING was the most famous prison BUILDING in Poland COUNTRY or in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE where the first Marshal Pilsudski was imprisoned by the Russians .

By coincidence the building BUILDING was right across the street DLF from there .

So , we located ourselves .

I 'll tell you a little story about this as a side piece that happened in Hollywood between me and a Jew from Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

Anyway , so my sister became the housekeeper .

She never did that before .

She had housekeepers .

She had everything .

She did n't even know how to make a glass of tea , like any young woman .

After a while my father says what did we achieve .

Where is Mother ?

We escaped to save our skin and we do n't even know where Mother is .

And here again he appointed that my oldest brother , who passed away last year , and me to go back to Lodz POPULATED_PLACE to look for Mother .

Q. I just want to ask you a question .

First of all , how long were you in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE about ?

A. A few weeks .

Q. Were the conditions any better there ?

A. Just ask everything .

You did not feel the Germans on top of you .

It was still reigned by a Polish puppet government , because as I said before Lodz POPULATED_PLACE was the REGION Reich .

Hitler reigned already that while the other was protected , Protectorate REGION they called it , occupied REGION territory .

The administration was so to say , not German .

That would be wrong , not Polish , but not German .

Not like in Lodz POPULATED_PLACE .

We were able to go in the street DLF and there was a curfew , that already did n't scare us , but we were not -- it was bad .

We knew we were in trouble , but when you 're homeless , you 're already a displaced person in the worst way , and you are an illegal being .

You do n't belong to this world CONTINENT .

God did n't mean you to be existing here NPIP .

The sentence , we felt the sentence already .

So , now me and my brother were delegated by Father .

Now , in the meantime it gets cold .

We are getting into the deep winter and Poland COUNTRY is very cold in the winter .

The climate is different .

It 's a gorgeous climate , but it 's very cold and lots of snow .

How do you get back ?

You can not go by train SPATIAL_OBJ .

You can not go by public transportation .

You 're Jewish .

Nothing is for you .

We could n't find the horse that brought us here .

The guy who did it , but there was a pole already available , you know these things develop like black marketing , who bought tickets .

In other words he would go to the station BUILDING and buy a train ticket , two train tickets for us .

It seems that now we 're fine .

We have tickets , all right , but we are still Jewish .

The tickets do n't say that we 're not Jewish , so we are taking a tremendous chance .

At least we can get into the train SPATIAL_OBJ now , but the train SPATIAL_OBJ is only with Germans and Poles .

Not only Germans , and a Jew to be in this , it 's illegal .

They do n't have to sentence you , they can just shoot you or kick you out while the train SPATIAL_OBJ runs .

It was a long voyage , and we made it home BUILDING , and to describe how it was , at one station BUILDING they recognized us and they chased us , me and my brother , but I was then 17 and my brother was 23 , no 27 .

He was ten years older than me , my oldest brother .

So , we were younger , and I will never understand in Hebrew they say Yad Elokim in Hebrew , that means God 's hand must have been watching over us .

The Germans were chasing us across the railroad DLF tracks in deep snow with German Shepherds and they did n't catch us .

End of Tape 1 Tape 2 A. We were trying to make our way back to the city of Lodz POPULATED_PLACE in search of our mother .

We still do not ( know what ) happen(ed ) to her , where she is .

One of our brothers which I probably did not inject before , remained behind .

My father would not take everybody .

He remained behind just in case to be with Mother or for Mother .

So , we finally made it there , me and my older brother .

It took days and nights .

We came there so to say , finally , safely .

Our other brother was there .

By during that time he was able to find out for money through people like in that particular prison BUILDING who would bring out information .

You know , everything is money .

Also , he was able then that he knew already to send in a little food to mother .

He found out that mother was in prison BUILDING without a sentence and was already three months and there she was , but at least we know that she 1s in prison BUILDING .

Remember I said before it 's still cold winter .

She had no set sentence .

We did n't know that she 's coming home BUILDING at a certain date where we can go there and receive her .

So , again , me , being that I was the best German speaker in the house BUILDING or learned German in school BUILDING -- and also because of my age .

We also had still that we lured ourselves with the impression that they would n't hurt a woman or they would n't hurt the young boy .

They 're just out for the real Jews .

So , I was the one who every morning went in front of the prison BUILDING across the street DLF from the prison BUILDING .

The city POPULATED_PLACE was almost already clean of Jews .

I stood there .

I asked myself very often , I wore a coat , I wore a hat , maybe it was earmuffs or the earmuffs came from the hat , how I lasted a whole freezing day , day in and day out with my eyes glued on the main door DLF , the gate DLF of the prison BUILDING hoping that Mother will come out .

If we knew the sentence , we would only have to go there or wait until she comes .

We did n't know that .

This took maybe a month or six weeks .

I really do n't know , but day after day .

Nothing to eat .

God forbid , not a little warm coffee or water because the surroundings was already German .

I did n't have a chance to go to a door DLF and knock and say give me a drink of water or maybe hot coffee .

How I survived it , just like most of the things are unexplainable and one day me standing there like an idiot watching if Mommy comes out , I come home BUILDING Mommy is home BUILDING .

They let her out the back DLF door .

Half of her was left , maybe less .

Three months .

Now you remember why she was there .

She went with the receipt to be paid for what they confiscated all our businesses BUILDING .

So instead of that , they stuck her in prison BUILDING without a sentence .

Finally , we had Mother .

So now , the family is divided .

Three of us , me , my brother and the one that was left behind to wait for mother and Mother are here .

Father and the rest of the family are there .

How do you bring this thing together now .

Where is it better to be ?

Should we go there ?

Should they come here .

The first decision was that we should try to get Father back to Mother .

To go into detail how you accomplish a thing like that will be just -- I lack sometimes the expressions , getting into formalities .

We got Father back , by horse and buggy SPATIAL_OBJ somehow through payments , through monies , through smuggling .

You had to smuggle from Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE to Lodz POPULATED_PLACE , because it was a border DLF already .

The border DLF was in Kolushki POPULATED_PLACE .

So , finally , the family is getting to be together .

Father is back , but the other two brothers , the sister and the baby , remained in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

We 're talking not still about 1940 .

This is 1940 because Mother went with this receipt in 1939 .

She came out it was already 1940 , the very beginning of it , the winter of 1940 .

So , part of the family remains stuck there and we are stuck here .

We never heard of them again .

The only thing that came through was this picture once in the mail , in 1941 .

So , we were lucky .

That was the last sign of their life .

Q. This is a picture of your brother ?

A. Of my brother , yes .

This is my brother .

We were like twins , because we were the two youngest in the family .

Show it please .

Show my brother .

But let me tell you the story of the picture .

See , if he can get the piece -- you see that .

Should I tell the story of the picture ?

Q. Well , I think you should continue on with the story ?

A. So , now we are in Lodz POPULATED_PLACE .

It was not yet a Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

It was not yet a Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE , and the other part of the family is in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

Q. Could you communicate ?

A. In the beginning there was mail .

No telephone , no thing like that .

There was mail for a while , yes , that 's how this arrived .

For a very short time there was a normal mail connection .

No other connection .

Good question .

As I said , I promised to tell the truth so instead of saying there was no mail , there was mail , quite a long time .

Where are we now ?

What do you want to know ?

Q. Your father and part of your family returned to Lodz POPULATED_PLACE ?

A. So , now Lodz POPULATED_PLACE started developing and developing and setting in motion the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE , in ' 41 .

In ' 40 it was closed .

They started in ' 40 , but when the fences DLF were created and the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE was locked that was ' 41 .

And if I 'm a little off on the dates , you 'll have to forgive me because I did n't have a calendar .

I did n't like today do everything on a calendar and I did n't write a diary .

So , dates might be -- not might be , will be , not correct .

At the time we still had three of them there , and then one returned .

His son , who is the lawyer now , through him I got to write this to the museum BUILDING to begin with .

Two lives start , there are there and we are here and somehow it was considered a plus rather than a minus because the family is divided .

If one would n't survive , if Lodz POPULATED_PLACE will not survive , Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE will survive .

Because we could have reunited ourselves by the very primitive ways of communication as Father came as my other brother came .

All of the rest could have come , too , but it was more logical to have it divided .

You remember in the Bible when Jacob divided his riches so if he 's caught by his brother Esau they all should n't get lost .

That 's how we did it .

Father decided to already have an apartment INT_SPACE there .

Sister was the houselady , the baby was growing .

God knows how old the baby was when it disappeared .

We do n't know .

That 's how the situation is now , or established itself to that .

We were here and they were there .

Until the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE started closing , and all the new chapter of living in a Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE , seeing the creation of it and all true to life in the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

Q. Can you tell me how your daily life was .

How things -- ?

A. Daily life in Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE depending on what the Germans had in store for us .

Q. I 'm sorry , first of all tell me how you got to the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

Were you in the same neighborhood POPULATED_PLACE ?

A. We happened to live -- and I answered it to you before , in the Jewish POPULATED_PLACE neighborhood .

The very Jewish POPULATED_PLACE neighborhood .

As a matter of fact , I have there a picture of the synagogue BUILDING which was destroyed which was on our street DLF .

The Germans dynamited the synagogue BUILDING .

The night that I was sleeping in my sister BUILDING 's house when she still had her apartment INT_SPACE , that 's how early they did it .

They laid around dynamite for days or weeks because a little before that , they dynamited the Polish heroes monument , you call it Kosciusko , and then they drove over with a tank SPATIAL_OBJ and they put a chain on his neck and they pulled him down .

Then they destroyed the synagogue BUILDING , and why to hell they needed an excuse , they needed excuses for nothing , they said because the Jews destroyed the monument of Kosciusko , so the Poles dynamited in revenge the synagogue BUILDING .

Ridiculous .

So , then they started forming the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

They just chased section POPULATED_PLACE by section POPULATED_PLACE into the territory REGION , and you had to find yourself a place NPIP where to get into .

In other words , we took in two families .

Apartments INT_SPACE at home BUILDING were n't as big as here NPIP .

Ours was a two INT_SPACE bedroom apartment INT_SPACE .

By today 's standard , it would be one bedroom INT_SPACE and one big salon INT_SPACE , what you called with beautiful furniture SPATIAL_OBJ , in case like ours , because we were on the well to do side .

Now , every room INT_SPACE was a room INT_SPACE for another family to live .

So , we got all squeezed in .

The Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE became an Arbeitslager POPULATED_PLACE so to say .

It 's the best I can describe it .

Not a complete concentration POPULATED_PLACE camp , which actually it is recognized as because it has fence DLF .

It was high fence DLF all around with guards .

The signs , where they had the few gates DLF of entries , I do n't know if anybody ever told you that what the sign said " Wohngebiet der Juden " , ( it ) means that 's where the Jews live , " Betreten verboten " , _ it 's forbidden to get in . "

Seuchengefahr " , it 's danger of the plague .

Those were the signs .

So , we start forming factories BUILDING of all kinds .

My brother in law which I mentioned before , was one of the top millinery producers before the war .

The whole family .

So , he founded we called a resort BUILDING , a factory BUILDING , a place to work .

We had 500 people working .

We made 02:12 :)) flour -- all for the Germans .

In other words , everyday German SPATIAL_OBJ trucks would come into the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE and pick up productions of all kinds .

Shoes , clothing , even uniforms , military uniforms -- and here I 'll tell you right away with connection my brother - in - law .

So , that 's why I worked in a millinery BUILDING shop which had 500 women and men working .

We made the most beautiful things for the Germans .

Trimmings and flowers and earrings and hats for the German population .

Other people made shoes .

My brother worked in a shoe BUILDING factory because we were from shoes .

Whatever anybody was able to contribute to a factory BUILDING , did , because otherwise we did n't get soup .

If you did not work you did n't get your ration to begin with , but if you worked , you also get a soup .

The soup consisted of some water with some dirt in it , but 1 t was very important to have it .

Everybody worked because what else ?

You could n't go on the street DLF , they would shoot you .

You had to work .

Q. What age people worked ?

What age range were the workers ?

A. Good question .

You led me into this horrible scene .

What did I leave out before , what I always leave out .

Starting from 12 years , in May of ' 42 , I do n't know if you ever heard this one , I 'm jumping over a lot now because you led me into it .

Announcements came out -- it was a beautiful sunny day and I was on my way home BUILDING from work , because we had a home BUILDING and a place BUILDING to work .

If the home BUILDING had ten people instead of two people , or if the home BUILDING was cold or without water or without facilities , but that was the place where you went to sleep over .

On the way home BUILDING there was announcement .

What do you call what you call when you put announcements on the walls DLF .

There 's an English word for it .

Mother 's should prepare children up to ten years old in front of the building BUILDING to be picked up by trucks SPATIAL_OBJ because they are unproductive .

This answers your question , and they do n't earn their ration .

I always tell the way I was tortured , but I never leave out in conjunction with this , this scene .

I think of all the atrocities , and everybody knows that there is piles of shoes in Auschwitz POPULATED_PLACE and everywhere else , but to be present when this announcement came up , when I walked into the garden DLF of my building BUILDING where we live and I seen mother 's tearing the skin off their flesh .

They had to prepare their children for next day to be given away .

Now , what could be a bigger crime than that ?

All the crimes I will tell you about , or I will not tell you about , all of them together in my judgment and I always feel it that way , if I would be able to come in front of the United Nations and I would tell this story only .

The following day , trucks SPATIAL_OBJ were coming down the street DLF .

Me and my brother , the father of Mark , the lawyer , were on the roof DLF top .

We made it to the roof DLF top for two reasons .

One , we wanted to see what was going on better , but mainly because we were afraid to be in the building BUILDING because the mother 's just did n't deliver the children on a silver platter .

The Germans had to break in doors DLF , and they did .

These " Herrenvolkz " , these proud bastards , sorry if I have to call them that , were going door to door DLF breaking in the doors DLF with the carabins SPATIAL_OBJ , grabbed the children and throw them on trucks SPATIAL_OBJ .

We seen it from the roof DLF top with my brother .

Is n't that heartbreaking .

Can this ever come out of your mind ?

Can this be forgiven ?

Moses was taken out from the water ENV_FEATURES , right ?

But she put him on at least something to swim .

Here , they threw them on the trucks SPATIAL_OBJ and many times they tear them in half .

Never heard it ?

Everybody knows where these children went ?

They went to death .

So , usually I tell my own torture that I went through once .

I know that we 're leaving out a lot .

We 're skipping a lot or we 'd have to be here forever .

1942 again .

I 'm 19 years old .

My father was summoned to the Kripo BUILDING .

Kripo BUILDING is the acronym for Criminal Police because we were big criminals .

As a matter of fact , when I was in Germany COUNTRY 16 months ago , about my case , and I at once opened the paper and it says Kripo BUILDING , I thought I 'm going to faint there sitting there because I did n't see this word since then .

The Kripo BUILDING was the place in the chancellory of the nicest church BUILDING in the neighborhood POPULATED_PLACE and this church BUILDING fell into the neighborhood POPULATED_PLACE of the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

So , there was no use for the church BUILDING as a religious place , so the Germans made their warehouse BUILDING out of the gorgeous church BUILDING .

A block big magnificent church BUILDING .

I 'll never forget that because it was only a block DLF , two blocks from me where I live , where I went everyday passed .

They made this into a warehouse BUILDING for the Schmattes , for the belongings of the poor , already worn down Jews .

So , the church BUILDING became a warehouse BUILDING with that stinking stuff .

The chancellory which was across the street DLF turned into a torture BUILDING house , and that 's where we were tortured ten days , and I will describe you only the tortures .

Father was called the 16th of April .

See how Iremember .

You asked before if we had money .

They went by that .

They went by the status of the person , figuring that Father was a businessman , he must have hidden money and what they wanted was very simply , money , diamonds , brilliants and dollars .

The list was like this .

So , Father was in the day before , summoned .

Now , you know when you prepared yourself to go there that you 're going to be tortured and you do n't know how long .

So , what we did we dressed ourselves in a lot of underwear , a lot of upperwear that when they beat you , it should help .

It does n't help , but you do your best .

Mother sent her husband and now she sends her sons .

The next day , the 17th , we were summoned , the three of us .

We had to stand like walked up three flights , stand in the little foyer INT_SPACE , the balcony INT_SPACE when they called down the first one , there was more people than us .

First they searched us and took everything out from us , you know , because now we are legal prisoners .

By coincidence a small little pencil , and I do n't know why I had it there .

It was there , and they did n't find it .

I used it then to mark on the bunk INT_SPACE in the cell INT_SPACE when I came down , the dates and the day , otherwise I would n't even know what it is .

We had to listen to the screams of the other ones so my older brother was done first .

The screams were terrible .

Then they threw him down the stairs DLF like a ball , and they put him into a cell INT_SPACE .

We did n't know where he was going .

Next came the other one .

They took it by age , and then came me .

When I came into the other room INT_SPACE , there was a German sitting on kitty - cornered desk SPATIAL_OBJ , and he had laying strings(straps ? )

on the counter SPATIAL_OBJ .

The other German was sitting behind -- I am there now .

He was having a breakfast .

It turned my Kishkes , because we did n't smell an egg for two years now .

And there he sits behind the typewriter SPATIAL_OBJ consuming an egg breakfast and smells up the whole house BUILDING with it .

The first one behind the desk SPATIAL_OBJ , he was the first one talking to me , he says you are the youngest so you better be the smartest .

You heard what happened to the others , so if you want to be smart , talk .

We did n't talk , because by then there was n't anything to talk about .

Because the answer to that is if you already went to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE , the money already became worthless .

That 's just God forbid something happens here the dollar loses its value , everything became black marketing , and if there was anything little left , how could you give it to him .

Anyway , this is only besides the point , and as I did n't talk , now this I considered the only heroic thing that I did through the war because my father and the three of us made up not to talk .

So , the fact that we lasted and I did n't talk , I considered this was the only heroic thing , if anything .

Anyway , with a wink of his head , he was a hunch back , you must have heard of him in your interviews .

Suter was his name , a Volksdeutsch , called the other guy whose name was Schmitt .

This guy was a real German , full Aryan , tall and blonde .

Told me to lay down on the floor INT_SPACE belly down , ass high .

He showed me exactly how to do it , but he had canes hanging on the wall DLF or on the closet side .

I had to pick my cane and he started measuring out .

He tells me you 're going to get 50 .

You remember the Singapore story with Michaels .

He was getting six but the President intervened for four and a hospital INT_SPACE room was prepared for him .

He said you 're going to get 50 and he starts measuring out and I scream .

He politely stands and talks down to me , he says , would you please not scream .

I ca n't hear you screaming .

I ca n't take it .

Go down again .

He gives it to me again , and I scream .

He says , see I forgot to tell you .

Bite your fingers so you would n't scream .

I go down again , he measures out and I scream .

Again , he gives me advice .

He says , you know you 're hurting yourself , because every time you go down again , you have to start counting from the beginning so do n't scream .

Go down , bite your fingers , count .

How do you count while you bite your fingers ?

The sadism of it is what I 'm trying to point out .

I do n't know how many I counted .

I do n't know how many I received .

Enough to find myself in a dark alley DLF in the chancellory on the top INT_SPACE floor in a flood of blood .

If you want to touch here you 'll feel where the blood is coming out .

I had them touch it in court BUILDING last year .

Last week it was bleeding a little bit .

I said to my wife , it 's bleeding .

How could a nation become so murderous ?

My father died only a few months later , November 27 , which was -- he never recovered .

When we got out of there after ten days , -- I 'll tell you one more thing .

We could n't sit , we could n't walk , we could n't lay down .

Remember I said I had a little pencil .

When I got down to the cell INT_SPACE then they put me to a cell INT_SPACE .

One of my cousins was already there too , and an uncle of mine was there too .

Q. In the same cell INT_SPACE ?

A. My cousin was in the same cell INT_SPACE , my uncle was not .

I heard one of my brothers cry in the next cell INT_SPACE .

They broke his arm , and there was a doctor , I remember his name , Doctor Gilbert , who was also in prison BUILDING there and he tried to help him .

The guard opened the door DLF an shoot him for trying to help my brother .

This scene is also of sadism .

I was laying on the top SPATIAL_OBJ bunk .

I just crawled up there .

There was no facilities in the thing , just a pail SPATIAL_OBJ , but no water no nothing .

They gave us one little bowl of something like soup , once a day .

Q. Was it crowded ?

A. Depending on how many Jews they got in that day .

They did n't go by reservation .

One time I was listening through the bars DLF .

There was small window DLF with bars .

They made a prison BUILDING out of it .

Out of the church BUILDING they made a prison BUILDING .

We could have recognized the hearse SPATIAL_OBJ , because the hearse SPATIAL_OBJ those days did n't have at home BUILDING , have air balloons , air wheels but steel wheels , and at home BUILDING , the streets DLF were not yet paved , not all of them .

The main street DLF was , but most of the city POPULATED_PLACE still had cobblestones .

At once I hear the hearse SPATIAL_OBJ coming in .

So , I figured it possibly could be one of my brothers or my father so I looked out , laying looking down and they schlepped down a body , a corpse , and they put him into the casket SPATIAL_OBJ and then a few Germans came out from the chancellory .

Before they closed the casket SPATIAL_OBJ they want to take pictures with the body for souvenirs .

Now , being on the team of hearse SPATIAL_OBJ .

Hearses did not pick up one body .

When my father passed away , and we put him in the casket SPATIAL_OBJ , they put another body on top of him and then more on top , and on top of the roof DLF too , and you could n't go to the cemetery DLF , because it was during the day you 're supposed to be at work .

We , the three of us smuggled ourselves , we made our way to the cemetery DLF .

Luckily there was a neighbor in the next building BUILDING from before the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE , who was a grave digger .

End of Tape 2 Tape 3 By coincidence a neighbor from the next building BUILDING from where we lived all those years , because we lived in the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE territory all our life .

So , we knew more people than those that came in .

So , this person next door , he was out of profession , a grave digger .

So , when we came out of the cemetery DLF and he already knew that Father died in the house BUILDING , so he kept an eye on it .

When they started piling up the corpses , he watched for us our father .

So , when we came there he showed us he was laying already on a pile of bodies .

But somehow he was able to manage that he should be the outside corpse and he helped us pull him out , pulled ( ? )

the body ( ? )

and brought it to the grave DLF .

He had a grave DLF dug and we helped him finish it .

When my wife was once in Poland COUNTRY , I could n't go , ' 46 from Sweden COUNTRY she went there --- oh I have here the monuments -- she was able to put up monuments for her father and for my father .

Her father was killed in the Krypo BUILDING too because his name was Grinspan .

You 've heard of the Grinspan story .

They called all the Grinspans one day .

Her father -- the same year .

Her father and her oldest brother died within a week .

Families , whole families were dying within a day because everybody was so worn physically and mentally that if one died , out of grief , the others just fell in line DLF the same day and died , too .

It happened .

It 's not as a rule , but it happened .

You 're screaming somebody died and then you heard the husband died , the daughter died , everybody the same day .

So , life in the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

It was a work POPULATED_PLACE camp .

You went to work .

You got a ration of food which was very , very , very little because people were dying from hunger .

If you worked you got soup , and if you worked better they would reward you with another little soup .

They were out more to get the last breath out of you .

They fed you enough that they should get the production out of you , but for sure you should die .

You should not survive .

Q. Was there any way to get extra food or different kinds of food ?

There was a black BUILDING market developed which is a human thing , everywhere , if it 's Russia COUNTRY or even the United COUNTRY States .

A. Absolutely not .

A black BUILDING market .

I earned -- they paid us with Ghetto money .

See , I have some of it here .

They printed Ghetto money .

It was like a little government , police , everything was a self ruled thing .

So , I earned for my work 15 marks a week .

Bread on the black BUILDING market was 500 marks .

It was ridiculous .

Q. Was anybody able to steal outside NPIP of the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE and bring stuff in ?

A. There was maybe small incidents like that but it should n't even be mentioned as a fact because no , no , absolutely not .

There was stealing going on from one another .

Let 's say if somebody worked in a bakery BUILDING .

He would definitely be able to help himself to a bread .

If somebody worked at the vegetable BUILDING place .

Home vegetables were kept outside NPIP .

Now , that 's very interesting , too .

At once we would see on the main road DLF , like here , let 's say 95 .

The main road DLF to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE through Lodz POPULATED_PLACE was cut through the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

You see it on last week 's movie .

It was fenced off .

So , what was I saying ?

So , at once you 'd be able to see something wonderful is happening to the main road DLF , loads of wagons SPATIAL_OBJ , loads of vegetables are coming into Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE so we 'll get a ration .

You know where they kept them ?

On the outside in the winter and when we got them they were all smelled already .

They were frozen when we brought them home BUILDING most of the time .

Some times we were lucky to get potatoes that were useable .
