Now , potato shells was a very big thing , because in the kitchens INT_SPACE where they cooked soup for the workers , mass soup , they shelled , and they had the shells , the potato shells .

You needed a doctor 's prescription for a pound or half of pound of that stuff to have potato .

Now , when you say a doctor , you might ask yourself were there doctors ?

Yes , there were doctors .

There was no medicine .

The doctors were there prisoners like ourselves .

Coming back to my brother - in - law .

He suffered on hemorrhoids and at that time this place NPIP was still a hospital BUILDING not far from where we lived .

Once the Germans decided that it was a very new big building that this hospital BUILDING they want to change into a factory BUILDING for uniforms for the army .

So , they had a very simple way of getting rid of the sick .

They drove up with open trucks SPATIAL_OBJ on the sidewalks DLF .

They threw the sick out through the windows DLF , and they knew how many they needed to have .

The Germans are very orderly .

They had a famous saying " In Ordnung muss die Welt zugunde gehen " , that if they 'll bring down the world to ashes , but it will be done orderly .

If anybody escaped through a side door DLF or a side stairway DLF , they counted everybody who they got on the trucks SPATIAL_OBJ half dead already or broken bones .

If the number did n't match to what they expected , how many sick will be in the hospital BUILDING , the " Aelteste der Juden " , which means the oldest of the Jews who was in charge , had to produce other Jews to fill in the numbers .

It is = = how can anybody invent a thing like that .

If I would invent it , you should go and throw me out the balcony DLF .

Q. Who was in charge of everything ?

A. In Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE ?

Q. Yes .

A. There was a committee with an Aeltesterr .

His name was Rumkowsky .

You must have heard of this name already .

He was killed , too , at the end in Auschwitz POPULATED_PLACE .

They created a committee .

We had police .

We had firemen .

We had this hospital BUILDING , maybe one more .

We had doctors because there were doctors , but they were not officially doctors .

They tried to help you , but they had no medications for you .

Q. But all these , the committee and the police were all Jewish ?

A. Only Jewish .

Q. Were those good jobs ?

A. If this was a better job , yes , it definitely was a better job because they were out the whole night .

They were able to steal .

I call it by the name steal .

Actually we did n't call it steal but organize something for themselves .

Yes , it was a better job .

You could help yourself a little better .

It also had its bad sides to it , because you had to do things that the Germans wanted you to do like to round up people .

You had to do that .

I would n't call this a better job , because when it came to being , they only took into the police boys that had high school education .

So , I was one of them that would be eligible .

My father should rest 1n peace , not my son .

You will not .

I wanted to go there .

You get an extra piece of bread .

You can even bring home BUILDING and extra piece of bread to the house BUILDING .

But my father was too honorable .

He said not my son .

That 's afact .

Q. What was the general attitude towards the police and the Jewish council .

Were they corrupt .

Did the take advantage of their situation ?

A. Well , it would be not natural if in a crisis like that some people would n't take advantage of their position .

They were not saints .

There was a crisis that had never been in history and they had a chance to maybe grab an extra piece of bread or help somebody in his family not being deported because he had the chance to do it .

So , it was a bad taste , and here again my father did n't want me to have the extra piece of bread or the extra better chance , and there were more like me who did n't go , but not all that went , were bad .

They did n't go there because they wanted to be policemen or they wanted to be in this situation .

They went there for the piece of extra bread or little different treatment .

The end was the same anyway .

Q. So , the other people really did n't resent them ?

A. No .

No , a little bit yes , mostly not .

I mean this was it .

This was part of this life .

There is resentments .

Let 's say somebody did do something bad , transgress .

It could n't happen not .

The situation was so tight and so bad .

Now , I am not one of them and I am not sitting here to excuse them , because there were transgressions .

There definitely were , but I blame it on the enemy .

I said just enemy .

We were not enemies of Germany COUNTRY .

Jews were the best citizens of Germany COUNTRY for hundreds of God knows how many years .

We did n't carry weapons against Germany COUNTRY .

We did n't revolt .

They just came on us , I still do n't know why .

It was just anti - semitic Nazistic hate .

Now , how could 80 million people , and my teacher makes sure if you can read his writing to put the number of 80 million because he was afraid then that they 'll try to have a white wash , good Germans and bad Germans .

I would be too strict saying that there were none good ones .

There must have been some .

80 million is a lot , but we have seen the German people in action .

The devotion to sadism .

The devotion to their Fuehrer was above everything .

They committed the worst crimes in human history with devotion .

It 's endless .

Q. Do the Germans come into the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE or not ?

A. No , remember I mentioned before headquarters BUILDING .

At one intersection DLF they turned this in -- and also the entrances DLF , there they had offices BUILDING , barracks BUILDING , I would think it was barracks BUILDING .

Officers with the Germans and there was the contact with the Germans and the Jewish body , you know .

Also , all the transports SPATIAL_OBJ and deliveries out and in same through there .

When I said , I think I mentioned before , this incident that my mother sent me -- no I described it there .

We had to pass this headquarters BUILDING and we could have gotten killed , but this was a separate incident .

That 's what it was .

You See , it was one place NPIP .

My wife had worked in an office BUILDING which you call the registry , so to say , and I do n't even know what purpose this had , but in a back INT_SPACE room they were saving historic diaries of the days for later .

It happened to be an ex - lawyer from the city of Lodz POPULATED_PLACE who was in charge of this .

If anybody could have done something , he would , but 1 t was very little chance to do anything .

Q. Was there any semblance of normal life going on in the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE ?

A. Normal life you probably mean family life , normal life , yes , if you can call this normal .

You had an address and you had a room INT_SPACE and you had a mattress SPATIAL_OBJ or a bed SPATIAL_OBJ .

Most of the time , a few people were sleeping on one mattress SPATIAL_OBJ because there was no mattress SPATIAL_OBJ for everybody .

Definitely not .

There were wife 's and men 's -- you 're probably leading to sex .

There were a few births happen , very , very few .

That means they did have intercourse , but the funniest thing , if it is funny , when we came to Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE or rather Koenigs POPULATED_PLACE Wusterhausen ( deny ? )

the German proud uniformed officers would go through the night our bunks SPATIAL_OBJ with lamps , with lanterns to see if we 're not engaging in some kind of sex activities , so fresh they were .

Let me tell you , it took months after liberation that I even knew that I 'm still a living person .

Q. Back in the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE was there any schools BUILDING , was there cultural activities ?

A. Yes , that 's a good question .

Let me see .

Schools BUILDING ?

For who ?

One thing was , I played the violin since I was 14 years old .

As a matter of fact , my wife remembers it because we were school BUILDING friends and she remembers .

I played the violin .

I had a girlfriend whose whole family , herself , her sister her brother and her other brother .

The oldest brother led , conducted the orchestra .

We had a concert each week on the weekends .

On Sundays , the Germans left the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

They went from the Kripo BUILDING , the criminal police like in hell NPIP .

On Sabbath hell is not hell NPIP .

The main body -- the Jews were only in their own charge one day a week .

Saturday afternoon through Sunday .

So , we did organize concerts and my girlfriend 's older brother .

You say you 've been in Yad POPULATED_PLACE vaShem .

In Yad POPULATED_PLACE va Shem there 's an inscription on one wall DLF Milly Konsky _ will conduct a concert on this Saturday and .

L attended every concert .

Now , when the Germans came in , the order immediately went for Jews to turn in any playing instrument naturally radios included , and I had to deliver my violin to the city BUILDING hall .

I remember a cousin of mine I took along with me .

I was afraid to go myself with my violin .

While we walked up the steps DLF to deliver it , I said to him , you know what I 'm going to do ?

I 'm going to break it on the stairs DLF .

He says , you 're crazy they 're going to kill you .

He 's right .

I was off my mind .

Finally I brought it up to the top INT_SPACE floor , the room INT_SPACE was loaded with all kinds of instruments up to the ceiling DLF .

That was the end of music .

So , how did we have the few -- now we had two conductors before the war in Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE , Professor Ridder and Bergesmann ( ? )

who conducted one week and another week .

This young fellow who was only 19 years old , Jastrowski , it is recorded in Yas POPULATED_PLACE vaShem .

I 'm telling you truth , my girlfriend 's older brother .

He was a beautiful conductor , and the Germans never found out .

Or maybe they did because how 1s it possible that they did n't ?

Maybe I do n't remember how long this thing was going on , but we did have it .

I attended every rehearsal and every concert BUILDING , but I did not have my own instrument .

As a matter of fact we have a doctor in Haifa POPULATED_PLACE _ who also played in the orchestra .

I 'll tell you a little bit of a happy incident .

I had a business in New POPULATED_PLACE York , a retail BUILDING store , listen boys , and a lady once walked in there with another lady with two children .

When I had children come into the store BUILDING , you know , we had these metal racks in the stores BUILDING , would you please watch the children should n't get hurt .

Hold on to them .

The lady , who was the grandmother turned around to the kids and spoke to them in Hebrew .

Now , I still know a little Hebrew from what I learned , so I asked them where are you from ?

She said we live in Haifa POPULATED_PLACE .

We have a friend in Haifa POPULATED_PLACE his name is Doctor Fuchs , she says , yes he delivered the mother and the children , but he was one of the violinists during the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

Q. Did going to those concerts feel good ?

Was it a release ?

A. For somebody who has a feel for music , for art , otherwise you would n't go .

You would n't go even to a concert if you are as safe as you are in New POPULATED_PLACE York , if you had no interest for it .

For me , even today , listening to music .

You want to know how many tapes I have in the house BUILDING ?

Hundreds .

Q. What I 'm saying was it a special release in the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE ?

A. It was known to be , nobody squealed about it .

I do n't know how I myself should describe this incident that I am freely divulging even if it was something so good , because how could the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE have had something so good .

It 's a miracle .

It 's such a miracle that it was recorded in Yad POPULATED_PLACE vaShem .

It was Professor Ridder , what a wonderful leader and the other one and this young fellow .

I can not explain , no , how it went on .

Q. Were there other activities ?

Was there theater BUILDING ?

You do n't remember if there was school BUILDING ?

A. There was not supposed to be children so what for school BUILDING .

The answer is no , absolutely no .

There were not supposed to be children .

Now , when they took away children up to ten , you remember that , we tried in many cases to make false papers for children of 12 , let 's say make them 14 , or even 10 and make them 12 , but then you could n't open a school BUILDING .

Wait , wait , wait .

In the very beginning I attended school BUILDING .

When they chased us into the Ghettos POPULATED_PLACE already out , we ourselves just created a school BUILDING because our professors came with us .

They were mostly Jewish and we started attended the school BUILDING .

That was the building BUILDING , the same building BUILDING , but then became a hospital BUILDING and from there when they threw the people out from the windows DLF .

So , it was a school BUILDING for a while where all school BUILDING like at once I was at the school BUILDING with my wife because like at home BUILDING , there was no coeducational BUILDING schools .

But it lasted only a few weeks or a few months .

We tried to live , but we did n't know that we were forbidden to live .

That is the answer .

I think I phrased it well .

Q. What about religion ?

Were you able to observe ?

A. Well , it would n't be a legal thing to do , but let 's say if somebody died in a house BUILDING where we have that sitting shiva thing , there would a few other people to help out , but was there a place where we prayed , Rosh Hoshana , Yom Kippur ?

I really can not tell you .

Q. You worked on the Sabbath ?

A. Yes , we worked six days .

Q. So you were n't aware of holidays ?

A. Holidays , you mean observe holidays ?

You could observe holidays in your house BUILDING .

Nobody could tell you that you should know that today is Shavuoth or Passover or you did n't have matzos for Passover , you can be sure of that .

If you had a little piece of bread it was a holiday .

Now , you seen it on the Anne Frank movies that people were stealing bread from members of the family .

I described a scene there , I want you boys to listen in , I described the scene how I wanted to bring a piece of bread to my Rabbi .

First let me let me tell you what a rabbi meant at home BUILDING .

Here when you use the word rabbi you mean an official rabbi .

A rabbi by us was a teacher because a teacher was a melamed , which is in Hebrew teacher , so a rabbi was only bestowed on a real rabbi .

He had the top .

He had to be sort of say in our language now , a licensed , an ordained rabbi .

But we called our Hebrew teachers , those that taught us religion also arabbi .

And he did not have to be with a school BUILDING , an official .

He had a few kids that he taught .

In our building BUILDING was a rabbi like that , a very prized Jew to who almost every one of our sons , my Father 's sons had to attend because that was higher learning , not only reading and writing and arithmetic , but higher learning .

That was done like only one at a time or two at a time at the rabbi INT_SPACE 's quarters which was one room INT_SPACE .

That was his bedroom INT_SPACE , that was his living INT_SPACE room , that was his kitchen INT_SPACE .

A poor man , and he derived his livelihood out of some people could afford sent their sons like myself to him .

When the war started , not yet the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE , when the Germans came in , hunger _ came with them .

Just as whenever Americans , God bless America , came after the war , hunger disappeared .

Plenty of food by the red cross and by the soldiers .

You could drown yourself with food .

When Germans came , everything dried up .

And there were lines DLF for bread .

You could stay in line DLF for a night .

A person like my rabbi , nobody could visualize , and he himself he was just dying from hunger .

And at once I realized that my rabbi on the top INT_SPACE floor he was living in the same building BUILDING , is dying from hunger .

For all these years I was looking for a chance and this is why I probably appreciate this interview so much , because that was the first time in the 50 years that I had a chance to describe this scene that I was looking for an artist for a Chagall or for somebody like this organization now .

I at once put my hands like _ this(cupping ) and I started walking the stairs DLF up to my rabbi INT_SPACE 's apartment INT_SPACE as if I had something in my hand , a piece of bread for my rabbi .

I had nothing there .

I walked all the way to the rabbi 's door DLF which was in a dark hallway INT_SPACE , because at home BUILDING it was n't like here .

When I came to the door DLF , I started asking myself a question .

If I had here a piece of bread would I break it down to my father , to my family or would I eat it myself .

Because as you see in the Anne Frank story , people were eating their family members food .. At once I had nothing , and I turned around I walked back and the rabbi died from hunger .

All this that you are hearing today make up for the most cannibalistic happening and we know history and we do n't deny history and there 's book recorded .

There was plenty bad things happening and do happen at the time too .

Like Elie Wiesel was the first one to run to the Balkans REGION to say what are you doing here .

Let me give you a little break down .

Remember in the Balkans REGION in Bosnia COUNTRY Herzegovina once a bomb recently a few months ago and it blew up and killed 60 people , and the world was outraged .

You 'll be surprised when I say rightfully so .

60 people to kill from a bomb .

I 'm not talking about all the other atrocities that are going on now today , but he was there Elie Wiesel to tell the world that he 's getting sick from it .

Why is n't something done about it .

Now , let me give you a Statistic now .

Six million divided by 2,185 days comes to 3,000 a day , not 60 .

Three thousand each day , if you have a pencil or an adding machine you can add it up .

Q. I just want to get back to the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

Were there regular round ups in the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE ?

A. Oh absolutely .

These were called " Aussiedlungen " , liquidations until the final liquidation .

Naturally that was going on normal .

They would grab you , they would announce that you should come to a certain place NPIP where you will be -- but they lied .

So , they liquidated whole shops BUILDING with the things and they really were -- because they were robbing .

They said we need people that say in another part of the country COUNTRY or the biggest lie and the most sarcastic lie was when they came in ' 44 to liquidate the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE they told us being that the Russian REGION front if coming nearer we want to save you and take you with us .

They were robbing , but under the pretext that something wrong 1s coming .

The Russian REGION front is coming near because our side only the Russians could have come because that was east .

The Americans came to Normandy POPULATED_PLACE which was in the REGION west .

End of Tape 3 Tape 4 A. How could they have undertook to fight helpless innocent people .

All right , I will leave out the word innocent because according to them we are the most guilty in the world .

But how can they have taken upon themselves to make the judgment and to carry on such atrocities .

Q. You were telling me that there were actions and deportations all the time .

Were there any rules ?

Who got sent away first ?

A. Sick , anybody who was breaking down .

Age , like at one time I almost went though somebody told me if you go you will not live .

They told us that they need an amount of people at a certain age that they 're a little stronger and healthier for work somewhere in Germany COUNTRY because at one time I worked on the Berlin POPULATED_PLACE autostrada , building the Berlin DLF highway which was supposed to connect Berlin POPULATED_PLACE to Moscow POPULATED_PLACE .

I worked there too .

So , when they needed slave labor mainly the fact when let 's say somebody in Germany COUNTRY was short of labor because after all they were conducting a war and their people were in .

So , they would reach into these businesses of theirs , Ghettos POPULATED_PLACE and said at once we need a thousand young men .

That 's how it was .

Now , who made the list had a terrible conscientious thing to do .

He had to deliver a 1,000 people , so he had to sit down and pick , and whoever he picked he had to .

See , here again there is the big discussion amongst ourselves did they have to do it did n't they have to do it .

Are they guilty are they not guilty .

Well , they were made to do it .

They had no choice , because if they had an arsenal of weapons to say well tomorrow morning we 're going to give weapons to a thousand boys and we 'll go out and have a little war with the Germans instead of sending them , there was no such thing .

We were locked in absolutely helpless .

That 's how they did these liquidations .

The liquidations were actually work things .

So , if they did n't take him right away to death , not all the time , no .

You heard of the selections , once they took a group out , they started selecting who will fall to the wayside , systematically .

Then they needed more , so they had plenty Ghettos POPULATED_PLACE so they reached into the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE and got more .

There is no other explanation of it .

Q. So , when they sent people away , they still needed workers .

A. In Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

They needed somebody somewhere maybe better or like Schindler himself or my guy , where we were .

We also were owned by a slave owner like that .

Maybe he needed to enlarge his business BUILDING .

Schindler had a factory BUILDING and he needed more .

So , let 's say this guy of mine or another one .

He did n't give a damn for anything else probably than his own business , but he was able to get instead of going to the labor organization for workers , they were at the front DLF lines .

So that 's how they used us , they used us up until death .

In other words , they did n't waste a bit of us .

They used us until we died .

Q. Did they bring more people in when they were sending people out ?

A. They only brought in people when they had the full pull of it in the beginning .

Then they did n't bring inno more .

Where would they take them from .

There was no more .

Q. Maybe from other Ghettos POPULATED_PLACE or other towns POPULATED_PLACE ?

A. We had people to begin with from all the surrounding towns POPULATED_PLACE .

In other words , not every little town POPULATED_PLACE did they make a Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

It would be bothersome for them .

They incorporated all the small towns POPULATED_PLACE around Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE , all the small towns POPULATED_PLACE around Lodz POPULATED_PLACE , so the Ghettos POPULATED_PLACE were mainly in the big towns POPULATED_PLACE .

There was some small Ghettos POPULATED_PLACE , too .

It all depended on this strategic productive need that they had .

They did what they wanted .

They did n't have to ask anybody .

Q. Right .

So , there were people in the Lodz GHETTO POPULATED_PLACE Ghetto from around other places NPIP ?

A. Yeah , sure .

We still have some that we know now that survived just like ourselves who were brought in from the outside .

We know a few of them .

Q. Then they just got distributed amongst the rest of you ?

A. Yes , they were just thrown in there and the leadership had to place them .

And placing people was an easy thing .

You 're going to live in this apartment BUILDING .

You 're going to say no , and he 's going to say -- there was no choices .

You did what you were made to do .

Q. Did people get along ?

A. I would n't say not all the time probably .

There was n't too much antagonism , and then on the other hand , it was yes , because under circumstances like that where some helped themselves better to a piece of bread .

Bread was the key word .

You could have -- I did n't come across myself any frictions or even that I should be able to tell of .

The biggest envy was an extra soup .

I did know people that worked in the same place NPIP as me that were getting an extra soup .

What else did you know ?

You did n't care about your pants .

You did n't care about your jacket .

You did n't care about your tie .

You did n't care about your car SPATIAL_OBJ .

The main thing was survival , a piece of bread or another soup .

Q. Were women treated any differently than men ?

A. Were women treated different than men ?

Absolutely , no .

Q. How did you manage to avoid deportations all this time , for these three or four years in the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE ?

A. That 's a good question because I answered a minute ago that at one time I wanted to report for the deportation .

Now , let me explain what that means .

Let 's say that an announcement comes out that the Germans need a hundred strong men or young men .

So , the first thing that came to your mind is that it will be good there where you 're going .

You 'll get an extra piece of bread .

You 'll get an extra soup so some reported " freiwillig " , voluntarily .

That 's what you can call it .

So , how one avoided all the deportations .

Some questions are very proper that you put forward and not easy to give an answer to .

Because they say if they needed 100 out of a thousand , only a hundred went .

Who it was -- sometimes you needed to know somebody up there not to be sent out .

Another time you needed somebody in the higher echelons because we had a committee that should help you go .

Q. Did you know people on the committee who helped you ?

I personally did n't have any personal contact with anybody in higher places .

A. No , we knew who they were every one of them because they were visible every day .

It was like a prison BUILDING .

If I might call it higher NPIP places .

A big , big prison BUILDING with some people being a little bit more in charge of things than others .

Q. So , you and most of your family were there until the final liquidation ?

A. No , we lost two brothers , a sister and her baby in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

We do n't know what happened .

Q. But the people in Lodz POPULATED_PLACE , your father ?

A. No , my father died after the beating in Kripo POPULATED_PLACE in ' 42 , but the three of us , me and my other two brothers , my oldest brother passed away two years ago , and my other brother , the father of this lawyer passed away 14 years ago .

We , by unexplainable miracle , and you have a few cases where there are sisters or brothers , we were together all the time .

Q. So , you and your two brothers and your mother were still in the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE at the final liquidation ?

A. At the final liquidation , yes .

Q. Tell me what happened ?

A. What happened .

Then they announced the final liquidation .

Q. This was when ?

A. The Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE got liquidated between August , September , October of 1944 , but they needed a group of workers that will clean up so to say .

They called it clean the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE after the people are gone .

What was it to clean of ?

Nobody had a new suit or a new diamond or a new living INT_SPACE room wall piece .

For them everything was good .

Anyway , that 's what they called this .

We loaded that on trains SPATIAL_OBJ .

So , there were 500 of us , women and men .

We became kind of chosen because we were there longer than the others .

The Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE was empty .

We went out every day to work .

On trucks SPATIAL_OBJ they took us to work from building BUILDING to building BUILDING to pick up the stuff .

It 's ridiculous , what was there ?

Broken up things , the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE was already five years old .

Then finally came our turn where this Beboff ( ? )

who owned us , he already owned us there , so what he was doing was already as a businessman or rather as a function to guard himself or hide himself from going to the Russian REGION front because he makes himself useful for the fatherland REGION .

Q. For the record , why do n't you tell me who Beboff 1s ?

A. Beboff was a German , a German who was the Gauleiter , it was called .

Gauleiter means like Schindler was in his business .

Schindler was actually like a gauleiter .

So was Boboff .

Beboff was the head of our Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE , the German head of our Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE because we had a Jewish head .

You 've heard of him , Chaim Rumkowsky , but Beboff was the German representative , the German delegate , the German appointee for this business of this Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

Then he took us with him and he opened this business , established this business of building cement four by eights it would be today flats in Koenigs POPULATED_PLACE Wusterhausen .

So we belonged , our headquarters BUILDING were Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE , the concentration POPULATED_PLACE camp was Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE .

They took us to Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE .

From there he got his group further after delousing and after being there a few weeks -- .

Q. Wait you 're skipping too many steps here .

I want to hear about the trip when you left the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE , how all of that came about ?

A. They loaded us into cattle SPATIAL_OBJ trains .

I have to mention only a little thing , a few weeks or a few days before they loaded us , the engineer of the cattle of the train SPATIAL_OBJ was a Pollack .

Because you remember there was movie Shoah on television for nine hours and it showed how the Poles this was their job .

He was the engineer of the train SPATIAL_OBJ .

When we were loading these products that we were making on those trains SPATIAL_OBJ he told us in Polish Jidski , Jews do n't go , they 're frying you in frying pans .

Now this is the end of ' 44 , and we said to ourselves is he off his mind ?

Frying us on frying SPATIAL_OBJ pans ?

What 's he talking about .

He 's stupid .

He knew what he was saying because he came from here to there and from there back .

So , he had to be careful telling us because the Germans were around but he did anyway .

So , finally the liquidation came .

We were loaded into cattle SPATIAL_OBJ trains , and they took off .

No openings of any kind like you see on Schindler 's List .

I really can not tell you how many nights and how many days because we did n't know the difference between day and night .

They pushed us back and back until we arrived at the very big railroad DLF crossing and I assume that it was Ravensbruck POPULATED_PLACE because they took out the women .

The doors DLF opened and outside Germans running around with dogs , with German shepherds , yelling aloud " Frauen ' raus " , women get out .

And that 's how we were separated from our mother .

Then the doors DLF locked again and the train SPATIAL_OBJ went forward .

I do n't know how long it took and we wound up in another place NPIP .

Now we knew we were in Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE .

Q. What was the train SPATIAL_OBJ ride like ?

A. A cattle SPATIAL_OBJ train filled with people like sardines .

Not a place NPIP to turn .

No facilities of any kind , not even a pail SPATIAL_OBJ .

Now , you can imagine after a while how this things smelled , and people were just dying , falling down , sick or dead .

It was hell NPIP , hell NPIP could n't be that way .

This was worse than hell NPIP .

How long was it ?

It could have been a week .

I do n't know because we did n't know when it was day and when it was night .

We just heard trains SPATIAL_OBJ going by and passing by and they pushed us from one line DLF to the other and at once the door DLF opened , we did n't know where we were .

We did n't know where we were .

That was the only stop to get all the women out .

And when they meant out , they meant out .

Then they continued on after a while and not long after we wound up at another station BUILDING and that was our place , Sachsenburg- POPULATED_PLACE Oranienburg POPULATED_PLACE .

Q. Describe to me what was happening when you arrived there ?

A. When we arrived at Oranienburg POPULATED_PLACE , the doors DLF opened and a few guys were dead and a few others got heart attacks and died in front of us .

One of them two sons survived and came to America COUNTRY afterwards , Jakobowski _ was their name , and he was one of the leaders of the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE , too , and his father just fell dead while the door DLF was opened and we carried him with us and he was cremated because they had crematoriums BUILDING there too .

Then we came into the camp POPULATED_PLACE and there was big sign " Arbeit macht Frei " , Work Makes You Free .

So , we realized that we were in a concentration POPULATED_PLACE camp .

There were barracks BUILDING , full of barracks BUILDING , and we all got -- _ this was an established concentration POPULATED_PLACE camp .

As a matter of fact , the guy in charge of our barrack BUILDING was a German .

George was his name .

He was incarcerated yet from the beginning of Hitler 's times .

He was not bad with us .

The next barrack BUILDING from us they had Russian prisoners .

Every morning they would march them .

These prisoners were used for breaking in new military shoes for the German Army .

You never heard of that .

That was their job .

In the morning , every morning they got a new pair of shoes because they were heavy and hard .

They wanted to have them for the soldiers to have them broken in .

SO , they would march a whole day and in the evening they came back and they gave back these shoes and they got other shoes the next morning .

They were our neighbors .

Us they were taking out to work , and I remember at one time we worked at the Autobahn DLF , means the highway DLF from Moscow POPULATED_PLACE .

We built that .

At one time they took us to like work in the fields DLF .

At one time they took us out to pick potatoes .

I remember the SS man who was in charge of the group just for fun pushed one of our boys .

I knew the boy well , when the truck SPATIAL_OBJ moved , behind the wheel and squashed him .

In the evening he had to report to Mr. Beboff .

Beboff was waiting at the gate DLF when we came back , marching us back , and he reported " Herr Gauleiter , Ich habe herausgenommen 125 " , I took out 125 and I brought back 120 , and the reaction would be " gut gemacht " , well done .

So , when we went out to work , we did n't know if we were going to come back .

All this was already so part of our being that we did n't think of the liberation .

We did n't know it would come until finally as this our commander told us that the spring song wind is blowing in front of you , you will not live but probably orders came in that we had to brought back to Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE .

Q. When you were in Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE initially , how long were you there ?

A. Initially , we stayed in Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE a very short time , just like a passing through to the real camp POPULATED_PLACE , maybe two or three or four weeks , no longer .

Q. Was there a registration there ?

A. That 's how I got my number .

Q. Yes , but the tape does n't know that 's your number so tell me what really happened in those two weeks ?

A. We got incorporated into the camp POPULATED_PLACE as prisoners of the camp POPULATED_PLACE .

We were taught all the rules of what goes on and while we were there we had to witness hangings .

If there was a hanging , we all had to go to witness it .

You know , that was the duty of us .

Q. What were you thinking ?

A. What we were thinking ?

I do n't think we were thinking .

What could you think ?

We had hangings in Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE too .

In other words , why was somebody hung in Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE ?

I was stealing too , and I 'll explain you why .

Let 's say my brother , should he rest in peace , he worked in a shoe BUILDING factory , so he would bring home BUILDING a sole for a shoe .

For that he could have been hung .

So , if they caught anybody touching somebody , taking it , stealing it , he was sentenced .

There was no sentence , there was no court , they did n't have him in court like we have the thing now .

He was just hung .

They had places where to hang him .

So , and when they hung somebody to show the others how to behave , we had to go and be present at hangings .

Q. What were the rules they taught you ?

A. I really don't ... The rules were to keep yourself clean , or to make the bunk SPATIAL_OBJ every day .

There was no rules of any particular kind that I can remember .

I would n't even want to remember if there were , but I 'm sure that there were rules to obey .

They were all more like for I do n't want to say animals because I think I mentioned once today I do n't want to insult the kingdom of animals .

Q. But you said they taught you -- they told you how it was going to work when you got 1n , I 'm just wondering what they told you ?

A. They did n't give us any future .

They did n't tell us if you 'll be good , you 'll go home BUILDING or you will go to the theater BUILDING tomorrow or you 'll have a piece of cake tomorrow .

We were worms as you walk and you step over worms .

Do you ask then the worm if he had rules .

There was rules that they made up , that they obeyed .

Okay , it ( be)came very interesting in Koenigs POPULATED_PLACE Wusterhausen .

You remember I mentioned we had no facilities .

If we needed to go out in the field DLF , the only way to go out was into the field DLF .

So , in the night , let 's say if I remember it vividly , if I needed to go out in the night , to make a physical need , to piss or whatever else , I had first to report to the Wacht ( guard ) , the Heftlig ( prisoner ) # .... , that I need to go out .

You know what he did to me .

He made me run around the barracks BUILDING three time , not run around three times but " auf , auf , hinlegen " , I 'll never forget that .

He played with me .

He did n't get orders to do that .

He just wanted to have fun .

He made me fall down and get up .

I needed to go out , so he made me run around three times the barracks BUILDING and he had fun in the night to make me fall down and get up .

Exercise .

Another case , it was a big privilege in camp POPULATED_PLACE , because they had their quarters INT_SPACE there , the commanders , those who watched us .

I do n't know now many of them , eight or ten , so they had a separate nicer house BUILDING where they lived and where they ate , but they had to go for their food to headquarters BUILDING , to the nearby headquarters BUILDING .

It was a tremendous break or privilege rather a break if you were picked .

He would just go , come on here .

He picked one of the guys to go with him so they put you into a wagon SPATIAL_OBJ like a horse with two wheels and there was a part on it to go to their kitchen INT_SPACE to bring food for them .

On the way there , to the headquarters BUILDING every German officer who passed by like that had the pleasure of spitting at you , kicking you , pushing you and the one who was in charge of us did n't mind .

But this was a break .

Why was this a break ?

When they finished eating they gave you to wash the pots so you were able to lick a little bit .

So you would agree to be kicked around going one way and the other for this big break .

Q. You did this ?

A. I had once the privilege , only once , otherwise I would n't be able to tell you how these proud clean , tall uniformed like this he kicked , he spit , he threw his cigarette on you .

He pushed you over the sidewalk DLF .

I was doing a duty and the guy stood there with the commander and just had fun both of them .

Where did you ever hear a thing like that in history ?

Q. What about people 's health at this point ?

A. Health , health what is that ?

Who thought of health .

You mean if you sneezed ?

If you died , you died .

Q. Was there disease ?

Were people taken care of ?

A. Well , disease they would be afraid themselves .

Well , they always had " entlausung " deloused us because we did n't take showers INT_SPACE or wash so they threw powder on us , " entlausung " , and if somebody would be a little bit sick , they would shoot them .

There was no problem healing him .

Q. You had lice ?

Did you have lice on you ?

A. I just told you , yes , lice .

Sure I had lice on me .

I did have lice on me , so what they did , they would powder you only .

You did n't take a shower INT_SPACE .

Q. Did you ever get typhus or anything ?

A. I got typhus in the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE , right after crypo .

I had very mild case of typhus , yes .

That was also in another horrible , horrible horrible thing .

I feel so horrible about it , that I am even ashamed , I feel bad to tell it with all three of you particularly those two .

Q. Forget us .

A. My uncle , this is why I do n't want this to come to the public because maybe I have a chance now , maybe they 'll give me something .

My uncle was also taken in at the same time as us , a little later , maybe a week later because we were there ten days .

When we came out , I was laying in bed SPATIAL_OBJ sick , my wife , my father was laying in bed SPATIAL_OBJ sick , and at once my oldest brother handed me a little note .

Uncle Solomon , my name , is dead .

How did he die ?

He was taken into the Kripo BUILDING too , and they tortured him .

I 'm even ashamed to tell you what they did to him because it is n't .

They tied his testicles with a rope .

Remember I told you it was only cobblestones at home BUILDING .

They put him on a wagon SPATIAL_OBJ .

They had a wagon SPATIAL_OBJ with horses .

They did n't have acar SPATIAL_OBJ .

If we heard that little horse running on the street DLF , we did n't know who was next .

This little horse was like the devil for us .

The crypo BUILDING was if you remember before , I said , only a block DLF , two blocks DLF , or one DLF and a half blocks from where we lived , my uncle , too .

They put him on the wagon SPATIAL_OBJ , and until he came threw the half of block DLF , he was dead .

Blue and dead .

This you never heard yet .

Q. Who saw this ?

A. Who saw this ?

When they took him off when he came in the front of the building BUILDING , they threw him out , and whoever was there , my aunt , my other people , he was dead .

He was blue and dead and his testicles were tied with a rope .

Q. Let 's go back to where we were which was Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE .

A. We were talking about Koenigs POPULATED_PLACE Wusterhausen now all the time .

From Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE we were sent to work POPULATED_PLACE camp because Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE was not a work POPULATED_PLACE camp .

It was a concentration POPULATED_PLACE camp and this was supposed to be a work POPULATED_PLACE camp .

So , there we were not long , from October to April 21 , when the war started getting bad for them and then I said before Potsdam POPULATED_PLACE was burning and we were able to see Potsdam POPULATED_PLACE burning , so they returned us to SAchsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE .

When we arrived at Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE we were going to Berlin POPULATED_PLACE .

Koenigs POPULATED_PLACE Wusterhausen was on one side of Berlin POPULATED_PLACE and Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE on the other side .

So , we were seeing Berlin POPULATED_PLACE also in flames and pretty ruined .

We have seen the bombers SPATIAL_OBJ day and night going that way because we were in the middle , rather Berlin POPULATED_PLACE was in the middle .

Q. How far were these -- ?

A. We were about ten or fifteen miles from one side of Berlin POPULATED_PLACE and the camp Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE was also ten or fifteen miles the other side of Berlin POPULATED_PLACE .

When we came back to Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE , it was a mad house .

Papers were flying .

They were burning papers , you know , they were disposing of it .

There was anarchy because when the camps POPULATED_PLACE were there was an order .

You know the famous German saying " In Ordnung muss die Welt zugrunde gehen " , we will bring the world down in order .

So when we came there to Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE _ we did n't know where we belonged .

There was no barracks BUILDING for us .

Nothing .

They just led us into the gutter DLF , but at the gate DLF , we had to line up constantly and march out into the death march .

We did n't know what it was .

So , that 's how the death march started or became .

End of Tape 4 Tape 5 Q. Tell me about this work POPULATED_PLACE camp , what was it like ?

A. The work POPULATED_PLACE camp was exactly if somebody would open a business of his own .

We were building one item .

In other words , this Biboff , in order to get themselves involved with something that is almost military and need for war , because Berlin POPULATED_PLACE was bombarded by then and there was a lot of homeless .

There was no more monkey business .

He came up with this -- not the idea-- but he opened the business of building four by eight cement plates which then he sent or sold to Berliners to make themselves shacks BUILDING to live in .

They were already " auf Tsures " themselves .

That 's what he did .

In other words , he took advantage of the situation or if you want to say it was a business of his .

It had nothing to do with the German government anymore .

But we did belong to the German government .

We did belong to Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE .

The Shupos , or the soldiers that were watching us were belonging their command came from Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE .

So , that 's how it worked .

It was a whole set up .

As a camp POPULATED_PLACE how it was , we did not have hangings in this camp POPULATED_PLACE .

We did not have much beating in this camp POPULATED_PLACE .

Once in a while the commander here would kick you .

He could have split you in half .

We worked from sunrise to sundown .

There was no hours .

I remember like now , at that time , it was placed on a railroad DLF intersection .

So , we loaded the railroad SPATIAL_OBJ with the stuff and then by then already as we were there a little few weeks because that already was towards the end of the war , we started receiving German soldiers from the Russian REGION front without noses without ears , frozen hands .

They could n't even eat a piece of bread that was laying to them .

So , we already have seen how they were getting in their behind .

Yes , yes , they were getting it .

Q. What were you thinking when you saw that ?

A. We were thinking -- I think you said before if we ever thought -- this time we were thinking , oh , it was so good .

It was good .

It did n't last long because then they took us to the march , and it became hell NPIP again .

Q. Did it give you hope ?

A. Yes .

That was the first time when the hope was me or not me but that 's their end .

Where did we get news from ?

That should be a question to answer .

How did we know what date it is or what day it is ?

We did n't have calendars .

We did n't have watches .

We had nothing .

When the SS was having a paper and the wind blew it away , that 's how we caught up with the times .

It 's interesting , yes .

Q. Please tell me more about what the camp POPULATED_PLACE looked like , who was in charge ?

A. It was a field DLF , a big field DLF on the outskirts or on the side of this big railroad BUILDING station because what we produced was supposed to be shipped and received again raw material .

That was going on for these few weeks or these few months , but we were there .

That 's all it was , a big field DLF .

Now , you wanted to know if the Germans knew about us .

Let me describe you .

We were hungry , no question about it .

We have seen German women -- because this was in the midst of them-- German women driving bicycles SPATIAL_OBJ , not cars SPATIAL_OBJ .

In the back they had loaves of bread .

It turned our insides .

They were having big full breads to eat besides other items probably that she took home BUILDING to her family .

We seen them .

They did see us , and they did see the way we looked .

They knew that we were prisoners , that we were prisoners -- prisoners is too fancy a name because we were not prisoners , slaves .

Not even that .

There is no word to describe what we were .

So , that describes to you what it was .

It was a few barracks BUILDING that we built ourselves .

When we came there there was only one barrack BUILDING and it was n't finished .

So , first we built our own barrack BUILDING and this Biboff could n't give a damn how much production went out from there or what we built .

All for him was important that he was covered because he was in charge .

It was his business and he is helping the government , the war effort .

He was helping the war effort and he enslaved us .

So , probably he must have been a big guy that even could get a thing like that .

Do you understand his position ?

His position was to cover himself .

If he made profit or not on it that I do n't care and I do n't know , but I 'm trying to describe you what it was a big empty field DLF which was fenced in then , and when we came there was one barrack BUILDING unfinished .

We had to finish it ourselves .

It was already winter coming .

There was one water DLF well outside NPIP , a pump .

That 's where we in the morning we able to wash our faces .

We stood in line DLF half naked in the cold and splashed our faces .

You could n't do more than that with a little pump when you had 500 people to go through and here you had to go out to commandos , it 's called , work commandos .

Q. The entire working POPULATED_PLACE camp was you 500 people from the Lodz GHETTO POPULATED_PLACE Ghetto ?

A. Yes , that group , that group .

And we had women amongst us too , but not together with us .

Also , now , if somebody died , it was another privilege to get a piece of bread if you carried them out .

They had the wagon SPATIAL_OBJ on two wheels only and you put yourself in the front like a horse and I know a person who lives now in Europe who was good at it because I could n't do it .

Not everybody could .

He got an extra piece of bread to do that job , to carry out the dead .

The way he disposed of them nobody knows .

Q. So , they sent you back to Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE and you saw Berlin POPULATED_PLACE burning , that must have been hopeful ?

A. Because we had to go to Berlin POPULATED_PLACE to the underground bahn-- to the subway SPATIAL_OBJ .

As a matter of fact there were rumors that Hitler had ordered the underground to be flooded .

It was flooded , but right after we passed it .

So , through the autobahn DLF we came to Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE , but we did have the privilege of seeing Berlin POPULATED_PLACE burning .

Q. Did you see a lot of German people on your way ?

A. We did some , yes , we did see some , but they could not have any contact with us .

That mood was already hell for everybody .

That was hell NPIP came to be .

Then at once when we came into Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE , the whole thing was like anarchy .

As orderly as the camps POPULATED_PLACE were , not it 's an anarchy .

Q. What does that mean ?

A. Everybody on his own .

Papers flying , burning papers .

They 're burning everything .

But they directed everybody into the main DLF gate out and we got lined up into what became the death march .

That was the death march which lasted from the 25th of April when we left Koenigs POPULATED_PLACE Wusterhausen .

In include this into the 2nd of May , the day of Liberation .

So , we marched for about two weeks without any provisions , without any facilities .

Just marching , marching , marching , and after a while people were tipping over to the sideways with the SS on the sides of us .

They did inform us , like some of them that they are marching us towards Hamburg POPULATED_PLACE because -- and it was on television this week-- if the Russians reach us , they will call us all .

They , the Germans will kill us .

If the Americans reach us , we will be their -- they will turn us over to Americans as a good gesture to save their lives .

So , we walked like that and we walked and people were tipping over and that 's how this picture got soiled because we were sleeping in the mud .

Q. The picture of your brother ?

A. This picture of my brother , yes .

I did n't know .

If I knew I would stow it away because if any German would notice he would kill me .

Then after a while I could n't take it no more and I realized that when people lay down they give him a shot in the head to make sure he 's dead , finished , over .

So , we kept on marching , we kept on marching , and people were laying down .

At once I started negotiating with my brothers .

Now , this is really something that I 'll never ever be able to explain how the three of us were together all the time .

That is unexplainable .

But there is a few other cases like that too , in amongst such a big mass of people .

I started negotiating with my two brothers that I 've had enough , I 'm going to lay down .

I 'll tell you why else .

It was May , April May .

When we came to Sachsenhausen POPULATED_PLACE originally in October they bathed us , just like they did for gas INT_SPACE chambers and then they threw us clothing .

We had undressed , and a big guy would get a small piece of clothing and I got a coat it must have been from a dead woman of 400 pounds .

So , it became very useful in the camp POPULATED_PLACE during the winter , but to carry it on yourself in May .

Europe has a mild climate .

It was killing me .

It was hot , and it was so big .

So , at once I said I 'll throw it away , but if you throw it away they 'll shoot you .

You 're not supposed -- this is not your road DLF , you can not throw -- and the coat does n't belong to you , a coat , a shmatte .

It had not buttons .

I remember when the commander once in the morning said to me " Sie haben keine Knoepfe " , that I have no buttons .

He was worried that I have no Knoepfe .

Tomorrow you will have Knoepfe .

I 'll go to Macy BUILDING 's and buy Knoepfe .

So when I was outside NPIP working I thought what will I do now .

Tomorrow I will be on count down and I have no Knoepfe .

So , I found a piece of wire on the floor INT_SPACE and I made holes and I tied it up .

This was my coat , which because of this coat I wanted to give up in May because I could n't carry it , it was too hot .

So , anyway , my brother , who was the father of this lawyer , said to me , my name at home BUILDING was Schlomik , in Polish , " I have a feeling that we 're going to freedom .

Do n't do it .

Please do n't lay down . "

But by then if you lay down they did n't shoot you , but they kicked you .

They did n't want to waste ammunition on you , so they made you , they forced you to walk .

In the nights , they dispersed us into the woods ENV_FEATURES .

If you want me to tell you the last day of this march which 1s liberation so my brother again , he was terrific .

Once we were sleeping near a farm DLF , in the night and they had some bags with little corn .

My brother with his fingers managed to pull out a few pieces of corn because we did n't eat .

When we marched it was five of us .

Me and my two brothers , one friend that went with me to school BUILDING together and his father .

He then became a doctor in America COUNTRY and he died of cancer .

Anyway , my brother was feeding us .

Everytime he gave each one of us one piece to chew to exist .

So , one day it was the 2nd of May -- better yet the first of May we notice the SS reading a newspapers . "

The Fuehrer ist tot .

It was worth living .

Do you know what it means ?

Hitler is dead .

Better news we could n't ask for .

He was reading , but they were starting losing themselves .

Without the Fuhrer how can they exist .

The Fuhrer is tot .

Now , another story , airplanes SPATIAL_OBJ started flying on top over us one day before liberation .

Leaflets came down signed by Truman , Stalin and Churchill .

Stop the killing , we will keep you responsible .

Why did they wait so long .

Why did they wait why could n't they do that months or years before the last day ?

You know how the Germans reacted to that ?

They have an intuition of sadism like nobody else .

They threw a can of bloodwurst-- meat into the masses thousands of people got killed because amongst them was mainly the Russian prisoners who were a little stronger than us .

All these people had to grab that can .

Imagine their idea that they 'll throw in one can of meat there many people will get killed .

That was the first of May .

So , now liberation day .

That 's a beautiful day .

At once we reached a little overpass DLF as we were marching and the sun shined so good .

On the overpass DLF we could n't believe ourselves there were red cross busses SPATIAL_OBJ and red cross representatives and German officers and they were negotiating and talking and we feel that this must be a put on because this is the end of us .

They did n't let us cross .

It must have been 11:00 or 12:00 , we did n't know .

We did n't have watches , and I remember I was laying on the ground and I put my feet against a tree ENV_FEATURES just to relax a little bit and I was picking grass and I ate and we were sitting there and they were negotiating back and forth and we did n't believe that this is it .

At once , march again , the busses SPATIAL_OBJ get away and we marched across this overpass DLF .

So , the hours in the meantime we went forward until we reached an intersection DLF and there was a German again like this showing us that we ca n't go any further than into the woods ENV_FEATURES again .

Same thing as every day .

Dispersed into the woods ENV_FEATURES for the night .

My brother , this one , he was a hero , really .

He had a little can on him all the time , and as we were marching at the risk of being shot he would run over if there was mud , and he would grab a can of this and that would be our supper in the evening , with the worms and everything in it .

He did it every day .

So , they moved us in there .

Yes , I must give credits to the Czechoslovakians .

We were marching geographically as Poles , and the Poles even then were anti - semitic , but at once geographically we were able to blend ourselves into Czechoslovakia COUNTRY which is next on the map geographically , and these Czech 's took care of us .

They watched over us .

They knew we were Jewish that we are in bigger trouble than them .

In the evening , in the night , they helped us get leaves together to make a place NPIP to lay down .

I 'm talking now about liberation day .

So , we did all that , and my brother had managed to grab a piece of supper for us , in the can of worms with everything in it , with the grubs , and I lay down on the ground like that and I pushed it over , my can , with my foot .

There went our dinner .

My brother got himself again -- now it 's a dispersement .

Everybody lays there , all kinds of nationalities .

God knows how far and he went to find another pan , and he did n't see it .

He went .

After a long time , me and my brother standing there we lost him .

At once we see a bundle is moving forward like a pile of something is moving towards us .

We notice that our brother is coming and he brought a can of food .

He said we do n't need it no more , we are free .

Free , will you stop saying that , we 're going to get killed .

Where do you get what do you mean we are free .

Do n't you see everybody is here NPIP .

And a little while later a green Opel SPATIAL_OBJ car , those days with the step on the side , drove in , and a Russian officer said zdrastvjete , he was Russian because there were many Russians , so we started believing that we were free .

The rain started drizzling a little bit .

The day came to an end and we say to ourselves , if it 's true and everybody starts going out to the main road DLF and we say to ourselves , we 're Jews .

Let 's wait a little longer .

If it 's true , we waited that long , let 's wait a little longer , but the woods ENV_FEATURES were getting empty and also we noticed that Germans were kind of coming and mixing amongst us and tearing off their epaulets and throwing their uniforms away , the big heroes .

At once they 're not anymore heroes .

Something -- we could n't add it up .

Also we decided also to go out .

So as we went out towards the main road DLF because we knew where we came in , the corn was already that high on the side of the road DLF .

At once we notice a German on a horse with a column of horses like this .

He did n't know that it 's over , so we could have gotten killed .

We laid down on the side of the corn and they passed and we went forward .

We came to the main road DLF .

Americans with the pistols like that , like about every 20 or 30 feet .

We could n't believe it .

The Germans like this , their tanks SPATIAL_OBJ taken and we 're free .

I was hospitalized right after this .

Let me get to it .

We did n't know English .

In other words , the Russians and the Americans ( ? )

came together .

So , we went --we came out to the road DLF where the American REGION side was which was good .

The American boys showed like this .

We did n't know what they meant .

The Red BUILDING Cross is waiting for us there .

Until we understood what , so we were going there and in the middle of the road DLF the Germans were already like this , prisoners , with the tanks SPATIAL_OBJ with all the machinery and we could n't walk no more .

We did n't know how far it was so we got in in a tank SPATIAL_OBJ .

The soldiers helped us on the tanks SPATIAL_OBJ and the Germans were leading the tanks SPATIAL_OBJ .

I came up on this tank SPATIAL_OBJ , in front where the driver was , was lying a bacon , a big piece of bacon .

It was green and I ate it .

I wound up in the hospital BUILDING , because I got poisoned from it .

Anyway after a short while of -- I did n't know right away that I was sick .

I did n't eat -- I mean I knew I ate raw bacon and after I went off that tank SPATIAL_OBJ the whole thing -- the whole world is how will I use an expression , in Hebrew it 's Tohu va Bohu , like in the beginning God ( when ) created the world .

We walked , me and my two brothers , and at once we noticed that on the left hand side was a white beautiful house BUILDING and three American soldiers standing there .

So , we went over to them .

The Germans were just walking passed like this with their hands on their heads , prisoners .

We went over to them and we started talking but we do n't speak English .

But they were Jewish boys , so we were able to communicate .

The first Jew since Normandy POPULATED_PLACE , which was a year later .

The invasion of Normandy POPULATED_PLACE was a year before .

They took us into that house BUILDING .

This was a German BUILDING house .

They fed us , which they should n't have .

Then they put us to sleep and we could n't sleep in a bed SPATIAL_OBJ .

It was awful , it was so clean and it was so soft .

The following day I got sick , and they had to take me to the hospital BUILDING .

The soldiers took care of us all the time .

They were stationed there .

So , they brought a woman German doctor for me , and she prescribed red wine for me .

Where would they get red wine .

It 's a war POPULATED_PLACE zone .

The boys went out and told us do n't you open the door DLF to nobody .

When we come back we will knock with the carabines on the door DLF a certain amount of times then you 'll know it 's us .

We 're going to look for red wine .

They came back in the middle of the night .

You 're not going to drink red wine .

We 're going to bath you in it .

We found a tug boat full of it .

That 's the end .

That is the end of the hell NPIP , but then you are a displaced person and you have to go through a lot .

It took until July ' 45 when we went to Sweden COUNTRY .

We went to Sweden COUNTRY because you remember when I told you my brother , they broke his arm , and they shot the doctor .

Because of my brother 's state of health , the Red BUILDING Cross picked sick ones to go to Sweden COUNTRY .

Very few , as we wondered all his time how is that three of us survived ?

Very few were more than us alone , so anybody who had family like two brothers , the Swedes took us alone .

That 's how we got to Sweden COUNTRY July 7 , 1945 , after liberation .

Q. So the Red BUILDING Cross took you to Sweden COUNTRY ?

A. The Red BUILDING Cross took us to Sweden COUNTRY , yes .

Q. What happened in Sweden COUNTRY .

A. In Sweden COUNTRY my brother was put in a hospital BUILDING and we were camped .

It was n't only us .

They took over a lot of people , and they had camps provided , like military BUILDING barracks outside of Stockholm POPULATED_PLACE , all over Sweden COUNTRY .

This is a separate chapter .

The Swedes did us absolutely magnificent .

That 's a separate in our lives 1s Sweden COUNTRY .

Q. It must have been quite an adjustment ?

A. If you want to know about Sweden COUNTRY , it was quite an adjustment but it was so wonderful .

They were so nice .

All right .

We arrived in Sweden COUNTRY the 7th of July in the city of Helsingborg POPULATED_PLACE .

People were on the roof DLF tops on the hanging .

People were every where to receive us .

Then , naturally we were sent around -- oh , it was July so the schools BUILDING it was vacation so the schools BUILDING were turned over for our use .

They brought us to the town POPULATED_PLACE which 1s called Landskroner POPULATED_PLACE , and they put us ina school BUILDING .

Naturally , they had to put fences DLF around .

Now , before we left Germany COUNTRY , the port of Luebeck POPULATED_PLACE , the Swedes took us over already .

We got undressed and all we got -- we got sanitized because we were in bad shape , and they gave us underwear only .

We lived in that underwear for two or three weeks in that school BUILDING , because they were quarantining us .

They fenced around that school BUILDING .

Swedes were only allowed to go to see us or to talk to us through the fence DLF because they were afraid of sickness .

After we were through the quarantine , busses SPATIAL_OBJ came .

They took us to warehouses BUILDING .

By warehouses BUILDING I mean stores BUILDING , like Macy BUILDING 's , like Gimbel BUILDING 's , you know .

The stores BUILDING were not available for civilians for that particular day .

We had a list of what we need to wear .

That was after the quarantine .

The quarantine took two weeks , three weeks .

The sick ones were taken to other sanatariums BUILDING and first they gave us three changes of clothing including work clothing .

Everything that a person needs that 's what the Swedes did .

I 'm very fond of all of Scandinavians .

You know the stories of Denmark COUNTRY or Norway COUNTRY .

So , that 's what they did .

Even Finland COUNTRY .

That 's how we wound up in Sweden COUNTRY and there we were camped for a certain while .

They taught us trades .

We were free people .

We were able to travel free .

Everything free .

Q. Did you eventually get your own places NPIP to live there ?

A. Yes , when we started working we had an apartment INT_SPACE .

We lived as subtenants , because while we were in Germany COUNTRY liberated the military , the American Military were registering those that want to go to America COUNTRY .

So , we were on the list .

So , we were not eager to have our own apartment INT_SPACE , but we rented an apartment INT_SPACE from a wonderful lady in a private house BUILDING .

Her son was a classmate of Ingrid Bergman 's first husband Aaron Lindstrom .

End of Tape 5 Tape 6 Q. Before you made it to Sweden COUNTRY , did you -- ?

A. I see what you mean .

I was hospitalized in a city POPULATED_PLACE called Hagenau POPULATED_PLACE .

A small city POPULATED_PLACE in Germany COUNTRY , in the vicinity .

But Hagenau POPULATED_PLACE was also a prisoner POPULATED_PLACE 's camp .

I mean , we were camped there just like others .

The Poles started showing anti - semitism immediately .

As I mentioned before at one point , we were considered geographically Poles so they put us to this district POPULATED_PLACE , the Polish POPULATED_PLACE district of the camp POPULATED_PLACE .

We could n't take it .

We did n't have to take it no more .

We knew this is the end .

We would not accept that .

We would n't stay here or we 'll do something about tt .

One of our boys , who happens to be now a lawyer in Tel POPULATED_PLACE Aviv , spoke , knew English a little bit , like I learn languages in his school BUILDING , instead of German , they learned English .

So , he knew enough English to communicate .

He went to the American BUILDING headquarters and by coincidence the captain there in charge happened to be a Jewish boy from New POPULATED_PLACE York .

We told him what happened .

He immediately ordered a truck SPATIAL_OBJ .

It was an open truck SPATIAL_OBJ or a bus SPATIAL_OBJ I do n't remember and he arranged to bring us to Bergen POPULATED_PLACE - Belsen .

The Poles looked what happened .

Where are you going Jews Jidji , where are you going ?

We did n't give a damn for them .

We were out .

That 's how we wound up with all the others in the big camp of Bergen POPULATED_PLACE - Belsem .

That 's where we stayed .

Q. How long were you 1n the hospital BUILDING ?

A. In Bergen POPULATED_PLACE - Belsem I was since liberation which was May .

It was still May until July 7 .

From there we went to Sweden COUNTRY .

Q. Can you tell me about Bergen POPULATED_PLACE - Belsen ?

A. Well , the camps POPULATED_PLACE in Bergen POPULATED_PLACE - Belsem where we were kept used to be a German BUILDING air force academy .

That 's where they camped us .

We slept on beds SPATIAL_OBJ and on floors INT_SPACE .

The hallways INT_SPACE were full of poeple SPATIAL_OBJ , and Americans were stationed across from us .

We never knew pancakes , but we wanted to eat something better because what they gave us us was still not the best , but the Americans were getting delicious food , so we would stay there with our cans .

When the Americans threw food away , the English could n't afford to do that .

We grabbed it , and that 's how we were introduced to pancakes .

Every one of us would sleep on a dozen pancakes .

You know we were sleeping in the hallways INT_SPACE , lined up .

We got some kind of mattresses SPATIAL_OBJ , but everybody was grabbing pancakes .

It was so good .

It became like an item to us .

Whoever had more of them .

So we put them -- where could we have kept them all day ?

We kept them in our beds SPATIAL_OBJ , and that 's where we slept .

And little by little , we started to develop and we were able to see a doctor and the fact that my brother was injured , the Red BUILDING Cross , the Swedes were already very active there helping out , so that 's how they took us to Sweden COUNTRY .

Were the conditions okay there ?

A. That question should be answered it was crowded but wonderful .

We were free .

We were free and little by little people were coming out of there .

Those that remained in Germany COUNTRY many remained started working .

Started doing business , started going to school BUILDING .

I wish I went to school BUILDING .

I should have gone to school BUILDING because I had the background , but if we would have remained there , I would have gone to school BUILDING and I would have been today an educated person .

But my brother had to go to Sweden COUNTRY .

Q. Were the schools BUILDING organized by the camp POPULATED_PLACE itself ?

A. No , no , no .

They went to regular German BUILDING schools , not schools BUILDING for us .

You were able to attend -- you became a normal person and anybody could have done whatever he was able to do .

People were out to help themselves .

For a long time we lived on the mercy of the donations , on the mercy of the UNRRA .

You heard of the UNRRA BUILDING , on the mercy of the American BUILDING Red Cross or the European BUILDING Red Cross .

There was no more problem of not being fed .

Even dressed , even housed .

So if at once we were housed and slept in a corridor INT_SPACE , to us it did n't mean anything .

It was wonderful .

Q. How long did this euphoria over your freedom last ?

Did people all of a sudden have to come to terms with their families ?

A. Well , it was a very horrible time because at once we had to see who do we have .

Where are they ?

Where are the others ?

That became the main concern .

What happened ?

How can we find them ?

Some picked themselves up and went home BUILDING , if that 's what you call it .

They found nothing .

We knew that it 's no good .

A few did discover themselves and that 's how the whole new era of life started with zionism , with Israel COUNTRY , with American , with Canada COUNTRY .

For once we were free to do things with ourselves and again , step into normal living .

Those things do n't happen overnight .

It 's not easy particularly we are displaced persons .

D.P. We were stamped D.P .. We were D.P. 's , displaced persons .

Q. Did you have any thoughts about going back to Poland COUNTRY ?

A. No , no .

I would n't be able to face it .

My wife went once from Sweden COUNTRY in 1946 because we knew -- she wanted to go to put up monuments on her father and her brother and my father .

She went for that purpose and we had already people there that did return so she had where to stay .

So , for that purpose she went .

But I could never have gone back .

I would never , no .

I was once in Belgium COUNTRY , in the outskirts of one of the city of Liege_or POPULATED_PLACE where(ever ? )

that also had concentration POPULATED_PLACE camp .

That 's the only concentration POPULATED_PLACE camp I tried to go into after liberation because we were in Belgium COUNTRY one year 1947 from Sweden COUNTRY .

It was a horrible thing to see .

Q. When you were at Belsem POPULATED_PLACE were there efforts made to help people get information about their families ?

A. Oh , definitely , the UJA BUILDING .

That 's how I found my wife .

That 's how my brother found his wife .

They were only girlfriend and boyfriend then .

That was in Sweden COUNTRY .

A. There too , in Bergen POPULATED_PLACE - Belsen too .

But we first discovered our things in Stockholm POPULATED_PLACE where the BUILDING UGA had every day new lists .

Sweden COUNTRY 1s long and narrow .

She was only then a girlfriend and there was a girls BUILDING camp .

It takes a night to come from Stockholm POPULATED_PLACE to Southern REGION Sweden .

So , I went with my brother o find his girlfriend .

Camps BUILDING for girls and boys .

Q. How about Belsenm POPULATED_PLACE ?

And my brother found his girlfriend , and she was at the other end of Sweden COUNTRY .

This is a very famous story .

One of the girls was showing pictures that were taken after the war of the girls and at one picture I see this is Grinspan .

She says how do you know .

I said this is my fiancee .

This is my girlfriend .

I love her .

She was -- but I had to go back up to Uppsala POPULATED_PLACE , the old city POPULATED_PLACE .

She was adopted by a non - Jewish family , a Christian family who 1s a very aristocratic family whose son was the president of the bar of Sweden COUNTRY , and the daughter was the president of the Library BUILDING of Stockholm .

She was adopted there and they sent her to become a nurse .

She was working as a nurse in a hospital BUILDING .

Anyway , it was before Rosh Hoshana .

I sent a New Years card .

But what kind of New Years card ?

Sweden COUNTRY did n't have Rosh Hoshana cards .

So , it was a Swedish small good new year .

I have the card until today in my house BUILDING .

So , she was adopted there .

She was 60 miles above Stockholm POPULATED_PLACE .

She thought that nobody remained .

So , when I found her on the list , I sent her this card and at once she knew I was there .

By then she was going out with this Swedish captain of the Air Force .

She was in a beautiful family , the Culvert family .

They were a very aristicratic family .

But when Mrs. Culvert recieved this card and then I started writing letters she said to her what is this correspondence you 're having .

We want to know who you 're corresponding with .

So , she said this is a friend from home BUILDING .

They said we want to meet him .

They invited me to their house BUILDING and Mr. Culvert went out to the woods ENV_FEATURES and killed a deer that 's the only time in my life that I ate deer meat .

They made a dinner for us and by desert time Mr. Culvert took me into his library INT_SPACE .

All the Swedes have libraries and particularly an aristocratic family like that , very wealthy , but he was kind enough to test me on the Bible , otherwise I would be lost , and I passed .

Then they started intervening with this girl that you see today .

Mrs. Culvert told her no it 's not good .

It 's an attraction with this Swedish captain , you never met somebody else .

You thought everybody is dead .

Somebody showed up , cool it a little bit .

Let us get to know this boy , and they came to my wedding .

We were married in Malmoe POPULATED_PLACE .

Q. You started dating in the Lodz GHETTO POPULATED_PLACE Ghetto ?

A. We knew from school BUILDING , not the Lodz GHETTO POPULATED_PLACE Ghetto , school days .

We lived in the country COUNTRY together a few season , one villa BUILDING next to the other .

I knew her brother .

Here is a picture of her family .

She received it from an aunt in Newark POPULATED_PLACE after the war .

You will recognize the cute little thing .

I knew her since probably she was ten years old .

Last week was our 49th anniversary .

The 24th of March .

Q. How come you decided to come to the United COUNTRY States ?

A. If you remember we were registered .

In those days , I do n't know if you 'll remember do you remember the Berlin blockade in history , when Truman was President and then again it looked like movements from the Russians .

It looked like a new war is shaping up and we decided enough is enough and somehow we were registered and at once we were called by the American BUILDING consulate that if we want to it 's our turn .

So , we decided to go .

So , just like this , we came with $ 500 in my pocket and a pregnant wife .

So , you want to know how easy it was here NPIP ?

When I came here that was in 1949 , Truman was President and I learned a trade in Sweden COUNTRY as a furrier , but there was a big crises and it was already past season and I coudn't find a job .

I came in on 29th DLF street to one person and he told me look you can not find a job now .

Listen to me and I 'll help you .

I know the chief of personnel at Montefiore BUILDING Hospital in the Bronx POPULATED_PLACE .

She 's a friend of mine .

Seven million unemployment in the country COUNTRY .

There are lines DLF for this job as a dishwasher .

Go there .

I washed dishes for three months .

Nice story .

Later years , I was always in business .

We lived in the country COUNTRY where my second son was already born and young mothers always go to more experienced mothers if they have a problem with their child like coughing or sneezing .

Talking about little babies you know .

So , it was on a Friday , by Friday evening I would come to the country COUNTRY already .

My week was over .
