By that time I was still washing dishes at Montefiore BUILDING Hospital .

So , a lady another lady came over to my wife to ask her some advice about the child .

My David , my youngest son , says Ma , tell her to wait later Daddy is coming he works in a hospital BUILDING . "

He did n't say that I worked as a dishwasher .

He thought I 'm a doctor .

He was a kid only .

Q. Let me just ask you a couple general questions .

What do you think got you through all this ?

How were you able to survive all this ?

A. Absolutely impossible to explain .

This question is nagging us constantly .

What did I have better , or what abilities did I have better than my other brothers , and I remember each and one of them extremely well .

They were better than me .

My younger brother was a much better student that me .

My older brother was the most wonderful mechanically and business like .

The whole family , they were all working the business .

It haunts us .

This was the strongest question that you asked today .

I was only talking about it a few days ago .

If you 're going to tell me God did it , I do n't buy it .

Because if I would buy it , I would agree with the fate of them , no .

I do n't understand .

We do n't understand how the three of us were together all the time .

Because you know why we went through like that , because we were shaved .

They did n't know we were brothers .

We were standing one next to the other , but the minute they would know those were three brothers , they would shoot either three or two of us .

Q. Were there times other than on the death march where you wanted to give up ?

A. I do n't remember such things .

No , because a person does n't live only for himself .

I lived because I had a mother and she did n't have a husband now .

I lived because we had brothers .

I lived because I was stealing a little bit to support the family .

You might want to know what I was stealing .

I told you I could have been hung .

I was in charge of the supply INT_SPACE room in this particular factory BUILDING and at once trucks SPATIAL_OBJ came in .

You know heads ( ? )

are sized by sizing , by Starch and once a delivery came in from the Germans with the big bag of some kind of a flour , white flour , and I was in charge of it .

I did n't care if this is chemical or edible or not .

What 's the difference .

If it will be poison , we 'll die .

And every day I brought home BUILDING in my pocket in paper a little bit of it and my mother mixed it with pototoe skin and made it something tangible to eat .

How could I have thought of dying .

There was a lot of suicides .

There were suidices , but somehow we were managing a little bit , this brother , like I said before , he would bring home something stolen from the factory BUILDING so we were able to sell it on the black BUILDING market .

Talking about the governement BUILDING , the Germans can arrest me now for stealing from them .

At that time that 's what it was .

I did n't consider myself a thief , not a bit .

I did something to save the family .

Q. Throughout this period was religion important at all to you ?

A. I knew it was going to get to that .

I am raised in a religious BUILDING home , strictly religious .

As a matter of fact I 'm sure you know what it means and I 'll tell you something .

I was reading the Torah myself one week , my younger brother one week , and a cousin of mine the third week in my grandfather 's synagogue BUILDING .

I taught here in America COUNTRY , a guy , he was just here in Florida POPULATED_PLACE recently , to read the Torah because he was nine years old when the war broke out .

Then he became my neighbor businesswise if Suffolk POPULATED_PLACE , New POPULATED_PLACE York , so he was not bar mitzvahed .

By coincidence he was quarantined in Sweden COUNTRY with me together , but we did n't know one another .

But he told me you know I was quarantined in Urkis POPULATED_PLACE ( ? )

skola , in Swedish ( it ) means a tradeschool in Nauskrona POPULATED_PLACE ( ? ? ) .

I said I was there , but there were so many of us .

So we started revealing one another and telling what we know what we do n't know .

Once his daughter came into my store BUILDING and says Sol , would you help my father become bar mitzvahed .

I said yes .

I have another story in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

Anyhow , I did it and then he told me after that that he wants to become a real reader .

So , I said if you want to do it it 's very tough , but if you want to , and he take me and anyways we accomplished it and he is -- my pupil is reading the Torah every shabat in Suffolk BUILDING Synagogue .

But something else , when we were in Sweden COUNTRY , remember when I told you about it was Rosh Hoshana and I sent a card to my wife , but the chief rabbi of Sweden Rabbi Jacobson was coming to the camps POPULATED_PLACE to organize religious services for new years , Rosh Hoshana .

One of the boys who is from Montreal POPULATED_PLACE and now he lives in Florida POPULATED_PLACE .

One of the boys told he you know we have a guy here from my city POPULATED_PLACE , Rabbi who reads the Torah .

So , Rabbi Jacobson says we have a here .

He came to me he says you know we 're organizing services for the holiday you 're going to read .

I said Rabbi I will not .

I can not emotionally do it .

He was desperate .

He said I founda , and I ca n't use it .

Anyway , Rabbi , it 's impossible because when I do it , I see my home BUILDING , I see my father , how proud he was .

I ca n't do it .

One day me and my wife ran into Rabbi Jacobson at the Central BUILDING Station in Stockholm POPULATED_PLACE .

He had returned from Oslo POPULATED_PLACE , Norway COUNTRY .

He buried 70 Jewish bodies .

He comes over again to me .

My wife was with me .

He says , Sol , whatever he called me then .

Will you maybe do me a favor and come to read in Oslo POPULATED_PLACE .

I said Rabbi , it does n't matter where I can not do it .

He was desparate .

So , he walked past in the station BUILDING waiting for the train SPATIAL_OBJ and at once he came back , I have an idea .

Will you teach somebody if I find somebody who wants to .

But we were camped outside of Stockholm POPULATED_PLACE .

Every morning -- but our transporation SPATIAL_OBJ , everything was free .

Every morning we came to Rabbi Jacobson 's house BUILDING .

We had breakfast there and I taught the guy how to read for the holidays .

I never yet read on my own .

Only recently this pupil of mine had his 40th anniversary and we were invited and we were up north and he called me over to show his rabbi he said see this 1s my teacher .

Q. Today is religion important to you ?

A. I am not observant .

When it comes yishkor , you know what yishkor is ?

On certain holidays we have remembrence of the dead .

The list is so long that I stay in bed SPATIAL_OBJ and do my own remembering of whoever I remember including my wife 's family .

I am afraid to say it while other religion is present .

To me it 's a little bit hypocritical .

How could God have done -- as a matter of fact my teacher , you gentlemen did n't know , I have books of my teacher the poet .

He was a son of a rabbi from the very famous city POPULATED_PLACE of Wilno POPULATED_PLACE ( near ) , Lithuania COUNTRY .

At one point he says : " we served you all our lives , where are you ? "

How could I be a believer .

If you ask me if I 'm a disbeliever I would n't say so .

It 's so tough to be a believer .

My father and my grandfather and we were from a religious BUILDING home .

Six million Jews of which 90 percent were religiously obedient and something like that could be lashed out on them .

When I say something like that you have n't heard nothing yet .

You will never hear the whole thing .

The whole thing is a tragedy .

You questioned this to me 1s a tragic question .

If I have to stay here and not being able to say yes or no , that 's a tragedy .

That 's a personal tragedy .

I can not say no because there lays my father .

That is why I can not read , because I see him .

I see him how proud he was .

He ran back and forth to that synagogue BUILDING being proud his son I was only 13 when I started bar mitzva and then up to 17 and then his younger son , every three weeks .

This is why sometimes I say our life is a very painful life .

We hurt , so to call us survivors , is wrong .

We are victims , because a survivor does n't suffer anymore , but we do , we do .

But go through for these many hours , go through every day in our mind , every day .

There is no such move .

If we go to bed SPATIAL_OBJ , if we go to wash , if we go to eat , if what we eat if it 's Sunday , if it 's Saturday .

There is no such thing , and when I told my dear friend , neighbor Mary , let all the names of all your dear children your family your preachers , your clergy , your teachers and you Italian people , very family minded people , how can you just ask me to start living a normal life .

When you lose one person , we lost one brother before the war , he was 21 years old .

Life in our house BUILDING , in our home BUILDING was never the same .

My father was a finished person and my mother got sick forever .

So , now you asking somebody who lost the world of every thing .

Forget about material .

Would you believe that the Germans have a nerve now to accuse me that I have material reasons for wanting to be paid .

Number one I do n't want to be paid , because if they want to call this " Wiedergutmachung " , many of us did n't want to accept it from the beginning , because that 's too high priced . "

Wiedergutmachung " means made good .

How do you make good for that .

I do n't know who allowed them to use this name .

They could have found in the dictionary of the German language many easier words to describe what it is than " Wiedergutmachung " .

There are many cataclysms through history .

There is only one thing that I 'm kind of grateful for , that they used the strongest word in the dictionary which is Holocaust .

You know how many people try to call their own things lately when something 1s going on downtown where the Spanish people wanted to call their faith Holocaust .

That means that they do n't grasp the scope of what this Holocaust was .

Because if this has to be the strongest expresseion is only because they did n't find a stronger one .

That 's exactly what my teacher said and I told you before I can not find when he got melancholy and he stopped writing and his friends said Yitzkhak you must write for history .

He says I ca n't find words in the dictionary words to write .

Q. You 're teacher 's name ?

A. Yitzkhak Katznelson .

There are streets DLF named after him in Israel COUNTRY .

Then you have the museum BUILDING .

One more thing .

I 'm glad that I reminded myself .

When I talk about Katznelson , I am paying homage to my parents .

Because to send two boys to his school BUILDING was a big expense , a big effort .

So when I talk very much of him , all my friends know that and they 'll know about it .

If you boys ever go to Israel COUNTRY , there is a museum BUILDING built and the name it 's called Lokhamei ha Ghetto- oth ( tape ends . )

I want you to start by telling me your name at the time and now at the present , your date of birth and where you were born .

My name was Bylash Sharf .

I was born in East , March 22 , 1929 .

Tell me a little bit about your family and your life before the war ?

We were three sisters and a mother and a grandma , and we lived a fairly normal life , a happy life .

I was going to school BUILDING .

Then when the war broke out , I was going to school BUILDING in 1939 , and in 1940 , they started to talk that I would n't be able to go to school BUILDING .

This for me was the biggest blow , because when September came and I looked out of the window DLF and I saw my friends are going to school BUILDING and I had to remain home BUILDING , this was a big pain for me .

I could not understand as a little girl why this is happening , and everybody was worrying and there was such a panic and everybody was uncomfortable .

Everybody was fearing , and they were talking that we should run away to Russia COUNTRY and to leave everything behind and my mother said , how can I leave here .

I have the children and the family and whatever I worked all my life for and to run away to Russia COUNTRY , and we did n't .

Let me ask you a little bit more about .

How large a town POPULATED_PLACE it was , what was the size of the Jewish POPULATED_PLACE community ?

The town POPULATED_PLACE was a small town POPULATED_PLACE .

It was a poor little town POPULATED_PLACE .

There were a lot of -- there was a trade like markets BUILDING , they were on certain days , and there were stores BUILDING .

People going to school BUILDING , the daily life , but there were a lot of poor people .

We considered ourselves better off .

We had an uncle in the United COUNTRY States , and he was sending us money and mother took pretty good care of us that we were well dressed and she emphasized that we go to school BUILDING and to be educated .

Were there a lot of Jewish people in this town POPULATED_PLACE ?

Mostly Jewish people , yes .

I think the population was around 2,000 people .

There were synagogues BUILDING and Hebrew BUILDING schools .

Just about the normal Jewish life what it was in Poland COUNTRY .

And your family was traditionally religious ?

They were religious , but not too religious .

We observed the holidays , and I was raised as a Jewish child , but I was going to -- I did n't go to a Jewish BUILDING school , so I was mixing a lot with Polish children , and I spoke only Polish at that time , and I was a blonde little girl .

I think that because of being blonde , and I realized that being blonde and speaking well Polish at that time , that I had hoped that this will be an issue that I will be able to survive among other children .

Did you feel a difference when you were a little kid .

Did you feel that the Polish children did n't like Jews ?

Yes , I felt even before the war started , so when you were crossing from one end to the other town POPULATED_PLACE , or you went out of town POPULATED_PLACE , someplace with your parent , you were always called " dirty Jew , " " dirty Jewish little girl , or you should go to Palestine COUNTRY , you should n't stay in Poland COUNTRY why are there so many Jews in Poland COUNTRY ? "

This I experienced since I was able to understand .

Did you make sense of that ?

This is how it was .

It came to a point that when we started to grow up and live a little better , so we had to hide if the Christian children did n't have as much as we had , we had to hide certain things like baked goodies or something like this , not to show off .

But you had Christian friends from school BUILDING ?

Yes , I did have Christian friends , right .

Did your mother work ?

We had a little grocery BUILDING store , so my mother had this and we had about three acres of land REGION , and somebody took care of the land REGION .

We also had a little windmill BUILDING that it was making flour , you know , so she was constantly busy .

I suppose when my father died and when my grandfather died , my grandma came to live with us and she was the primary person that took care of us , and mother was the breadwinner .

And your sisters ?

And my sisters , right .

You have a twin sister ?

I have a twin sister and one almost two years older than I.

You were fairly young , but do you remember were there 01:07 political organizations , Zionist groups or anything like that ?

Yes , they were , but I did n't belong .

I guess I was too young at the time to belong to those organizations .

Were you aware of what was going on in Germany COUNTRY after Hitler came to power or were you too young ?

When the war broke out people started to talk what was going on in German that Hitler came to power and he wants to -- not to kill the Jews that the Jews had to flee Germany COUNTRY or that they were not able to be educated .

We started to read about and hear those stories .

What is your memory of the beginning of the war ?

Did the Germans come into your town POPULATED_PLACE ?

The first , the beginning of the war we were bombed .

There were three bombs that came down on that little town POPULATED_PLACE , and some of my relatives were killed .

This was the first initial fear that I experienced .

This was when ?

1939 .

September ?

Maybe it was the end of September or October .

I do n't recall which month it was , but some of the relatives were killed .

What did you do ?

We did n't do nothing .

We went out with our lives .

Now , did things start changing all of a sudden .

Were there decrees or restrictions on you ?

I recall that in 1940 -- as I said before Jewish children were not allowed to go to school BUILDING .

But I think the teacher -- not the teacher , he was in charge of the school BUILDING .

He liked us so much and we were very good students and he kind of overlooked this particular year 1940 and allowed us to go .

But by 1941 , we could n't go to school BUILDING anymore .

What else could n't you do ?

We were not allowed to go outside NPIP the town POPULATED_PLACE , and people were just running and bringing in food , you know .

Initially people were gathering in the houses BUILDING and just listening what to do and how to go on with life .

I had the grandma and I think there was 01:10 an uncle that had two sons , and the parents were taken away and the two sons came to live with us .

I asked my mother and my two sisters , we asked should we run away to a village POPULATED_PLACE to hide someplace and the grandma was ready to go with us .

She was about 74 years old but she had from her son the other two children and she said where will I leave them .

So , she remained .

She remained and at that moment when we were ready to leave the little town POPULATED_PLACE for a village POPULATED_PLACE they started shooting .

So , we run away quickly .

We did n't know where we were running , but we run into a neighboring village POPULATED_PLACE that my mother was dealing with some of the people and we went into hiding into barns BUILDING .

They took us into barns BUILDING and we could n't go out during the day , only at night .

We were there for quite a while and we were going from one family to the other .

They took us for a while and then they said we can not hold you because at that time , it came out a decree that if the polish people will hold Jews , they will be killed themselves .

Or they gave them a prize , like five pounds of sugar to give out the Jewish person or the Jewish family .

So , they were not able , even my mother 's best friends , they said you know I would like to help you maybe by yourself but not with a whole family and you have to leave my premises REGION .

So we were wandering from one family to another .

This was going on maybe more than a year that we were wandering from one family to another and this is how we lived , 01:12 and then one day my mother went into a family that she was very poor and approximately her children were our age .

How my mother came to the thought to buy or to offer her money she should go to the church BUILDING and to take out some kind of documents that we should leave the place where we were born or the surrounding villages POPULATED_PLACE that they knew us , and she said she dressed us 1n very long dresses and scarves over the heads and we started to look like 15 , 16 year old girls and at that time the Germans were catching people to go to work to Germany COUNTRY .

You know we were working around the Germans , the Gestapo and nobody caught us .

Nobody caught us and we were like disappointed .

So , at one point my mother said she took the train SPATIAL_OBJ , she brought the kids for the train SPATIAL_OBJ and we went to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

I want to stop you a moment .

I have some questions .

So , you were hiding out in these barns BUILDING and fields DLF and did you have to pay these people something to keep you ?

Those were the people that they really tried to help .

They knew my mother very well and they respected her because there were times when they needed help my mother was always there to help them because we were a little bit better financially off than them .

So , but there came a time when the rulings of the Germans was so that they were afraid for their lives .

They were also afraid for their lives and of course they were ones -- I think once I remember that they caught my mother some place NPIP and 01:14 they took away a ring from her and they said if she does n't give the ring they will bring her to the Gestapo or something like that .

This was the people that she was raised with them .

Some were very vicious and some tried to be very helpful .

What was their reaction towards the Germans and the Nazis ?

They liked them .

The Germans -- in the beginning they brought in a certain prosperity .

You know they were wheeling and dealing and selling things , I do n't recall what kind of merchandise but there was a certain prosperity that arrived with the Germans at that time .

The Polish population , they I would say that they were silently working together with the Germans .

They were indifferent to the Jews .

They wanted to get rid of these Jews .

Poland COUNTRY had three million Jews before the war .

This was the largest Jewish population in Poland COUNTRY , and the Polish people were 75 percent illiterate at that time and the churches BUILDING had the big influence morally , politically whatnot and they knew , they were told that the Jews killed Jesus and the Jews are non desired to be there .

So , like the rest of the world , they tried to overlook that you are human beings and when you are a Jew you 01:16 have no right to live .

There were very few of them , that they were real Catholics , and they really suffered from this point , that the people are getting killed like that .

Your mother bought these birth certificates or identity -- ?

She got them from these other children ?

From the family the peasants that were there .

She went to the church BUILDING and she took out a birth certificate for both of us and from her she took her birth certificate from her mother .

My name at that time was Bronislava Bershenska .

And your older sister was with you also ?

The older sister got the birth certificate from another family and her certificate was altered slightly , but she was traveling with this birth certificate , right .

And these birth certificates said that you were catholic ?

That I am a Catholic , yes .

That I am a catholic , so where were we .

I have just one more question for you and you were going to tell me that you went to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

As a young girl was -- at this time was there a sense of adventure about this , or was it frightening , do you remember ’ ?

Ninety percent was fear , but there was maybe ten percent of adventure .

I think in moment of fear you can not appreciate life at all .

You were trying to run from one place NPIP to another , just to survive , just to sleep over the night , just for another day and to hope that someday this will end .

Now , your mother 's plan was to then go to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE ?

It was n't her plan to go to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

She wanted to run away from the territories REGION that we were known , or maybe we could be recognized .

So , we went and we bought tickets , she bought tickets for all of us and we went on a train SPATIAL_OBJ and this train SPATIAL_OBJ was going to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

There was a lot of people that they were smuggling like food and other articles from villages POPULATED_PLACE , the food probably mostly , and she started to talk to somebody on the train SPATIAL_OBJ and she gave an address to a German Volksdeutsche , that they needed help for their homes BUILDING .

The Volksdeutsche , either she was a Volksdeutsche or he , so they had certain privileges by the German government they received all kinds of goodies .

I do n't know if they received any money , but they were especially elite like , and they started to hire help .

So , my mother was hired in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

I do n't know where we slept .

We probably got up and got off the train SPATIAL_OBJ at night or in the morning and she got this particular address from the other women .

She was a Volksdeutsche , and he had a wife and four children and she was pregnant with the fifth and she needed help .

So , he hired my mother right away with my twin sister and this lady directed me to my family also a Volksdeutsch family that at the time I think I was approaching 14 already .

This was in 1943 .

She hired me to be with her children I should go to park DLF and to play with children or go with children and do for the children things .

So , my main job was to help a little in the kitchen INT_SPACE .

I did some marketing and basically to play with the children .

Where did they think you came from ?

We told them that we run away from the territory of Lublin POPULATED_PLACE , that the Germans chased us out and they took away our possessions and they called us Fluechtlinge ( refugees ) , we ( were ) chased out 01:21 from our homes BUILDING .

And as I said , I emphasized that to speak very well Polish and to be from a small town POPULATED_PLACE , we thought we maybe assimilated as other Jews .

In other words , our Polish language was so good that we could pass by that nobody should have a hint that we were Jewish .

So , this was in 1943 when you got to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE ?

We arrived I believe in late 1942 in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

It was around November , in the fall , and the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE started to burn the next year , in 1943 .

So , I was at that time in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

I was going for walks with the children and I have seen Jews going from place NPIP to place NPIP like hundred Jews together .

They were -- their clothes were torn .

They had the yellow swastikas ( means stars of David ) on them and they were going from one place NPIP to another .

I do n't know where they were going , but I stopped and I looked at them and it inserted in me such a pain .

In a way I was happy that I was n't one of them .

I could have been there among them , but the pain was unbearable .

I turned away and I cried that nobody should see me that I was in such pain .

When I was in this family , I think this was my mother 's teaching that we should all go to church BUILDING .

So , I asked the family where is the nearest church BUILDING , and I took the children every Sunday , and I dressed them and I went to church BUILDING every Sunday with them .

Around -- and this is how we lived .

My sister had an incident the older one she was walking in the street DLF and a woman from our place NPIP recognized her and she started to call her .

So , she run away and we were told that .

So , there was a period of time when we were afraid to walk the streets DLF , you know , how big is whole Poland COUNTRY .

There may be some people coming shopping and being on the street DLF , somebody can recognize .

So every moment , every step that you did , you had a certain fear in yourself .

There was a fear of being recognized .

At one point , my family , the husband of the wife brought up a girl and she had a document , she had dark hair , she looked like a typical Jewish girl , and he started to interrogate her and she had the paper and the seal was like of a penny , or a dime , and he started to question her and he took her away to the Gestapo , and he interrogated her in front of me .

You can imagine how I felt at that time when he interrogated the girl and he did bring her to the Gestapo .

But life was going on until about July when all of a sudden two Gestapos showed up in the 01:25 apartment INT_SPACE and they said to my lady , to the wife of this man , you have here " ein Juedisches Kind " , you have a Jewess here .

She looked at him , I have a Jewish girl here ?

This is not possible .

And she opened the bedroom INT_SPACE and she showed him Hitler .

She said , Hitler is my god .

How would I be able to hold a Jewish girl in my household BUILDING .

She denied it , and I will never forget this .

I was peeling potatoes at that time , and I became almost stiff , and he was talking to her that this young girl has a mother with another girl , and so she started to swear to them that it 's not possible that she 's Jewish .

Either her mother or the other sister is Jewish .

She will swear by that .

So , he said tell her and he spoke to me German but I stood with the back , not to understand from Jewish to German is very easily to be understood and I pretended I do n't understand .

So , she told me in Polish that I should get dressed and I should go to my mother .

I had no other choice .

It was July .

It was hot , whatever I took and the two Gendarmes took me down to the street DLF and I was going over to my mother and the fear in my mind what my mother will see if she will see me with the two Gendarmes going there .

But while 01:27 : I was walking with them one to the other said , " Ich glaube nicht dass das ist ein Juedisches Kind " , in German he said I do n't believe that this 1s a Jewish child and this give me such a strength that I recovered myself of the initial fear and when I walked into my mother , my mother saw me , I saw my mother is pale and 1s dropping like she 's falling and my sister and they start to talk to this man at the time , this wife of his just gave birth to the fifth child , and he happens to be home BUILDING , the husband and he was a high official in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

He was an SS man , you know , he was working in Allee Sucha ( ? ? ) .

Allee Sucha was like they would arrest in a criminal BUILDING court .

So , his wife started to cry .

She said how can I be left alone .

She gave birth and on top of it she was very ill I think she had a lung infection , pneumonia , and she was about to die .

I think she eventually did .

And he said to the Germans , to the two SS people , you know , I 'll go with them .

I can swear by God that they are not Jewish people , but I 'll go with them .

And he emphasized also that they are going to the church BUILDING with my children and he would never allow himself to lose his high position that the was a high ranking man and to hold Jewish people in his place NPIP .

He dressed himself and he went with us to Allee BUILDING Shukha .

When I arrived there I did not know my older sister was already there .

Once you go in there , forget about it , nobody comes out .

What happened with my older sister , she said that she 's from a village POPULATED_PLACE some place NPIP , but she had beautiful underwear and she wore glasses and this woman that she worked for , she said , you know , you do n't look like a peasant .

You look like you come from a learned family and you wear glasses .

Tell me , I think you are Jewish .

So , my sister did n't say yes or no , but she started to cry .

As soon as she started to 01:30 : cry , they arrested her .

They also took two Germans and they also brought her to Allee BUILDING Shukha .

When we came there I saw her in a different room INT_SPACE with two Germans and I and my mother they took us by train SPATIAL_OBJ , a trailer SPATIAL_OBJ car .

I looked at my mother , and I knew that within a couple of hours we will be dead , that we are already in the hands of the SS .

When we arrived there , they started to ask us about religion , if I know the religion the prayers , so I knew the prayers by heart .

We were prepared for that , you know .

Catholic prayers ?

Yes , catholic prayers .

So , one came out to me and he said in German , tell me you are really a Jewish girl .

You pretend to be a catholic .

I think he started to speak to me in Polish because when they spoke to me German , to us in German in general , we did n't answer .

We were standing like dummies .

So , when the same SS man started to speak Polish I told him , you know , if you will persecute us , do away with us , you will have on your conscience , innocent children .

That 's what I answered him .

I was only 14 years old .

I stepped forward and I started to speak to them .

That man that my mother was working for , he also started to tell that this is not possible .

He was arguing with them and give them all the details about us .

So , they asked my mother , they said they will make a deal with my mother .

That they will allow us to leave this place NPIP for three weeks and bring my mother 's marriage certificate , the death certificate of the 01:32 : father , the other documents which I needed , you know , and at that time in Poland COUNTRY I think I already had a Kennkarte and an Arbeitskarte , you know , so they released us , and I came back to the same family .

She was glad to see me back , so did the husband of the sick woman glad to see mother back , also .

And my older sister had no place NPIP to go because this woman that called the SS did n't want her anymore .

So , she was a couple days with me .

I went down and bought a paper .

Imagine that at 14 years old , and looking for a job outside REGION Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

So , there was a farmer that wanted help , so we put my sister on the train SPATIAL_OBJ and with the address of that farmer , and my younger sister went with her there and she remained over there .

And the younger sister came back and within those three weeks that we were supposed to deliver all the papers and identify ourselves , we started to plan to run away .

There was no other choice , just to leave the place NPIP .

As ill as she was , my mother 's lady , she was a very fine woman , but I guess survival is over taken everything and you run like animals at that time , and we started to make plans that one day 01:34 : we will meet at the main station BUILDING and take a train SPATIAL_OBJ and again to go into a place NPIP or maybe we will ask somebody where we will be able to work , or maybe we 'll go to the Russian DLF border and maybe we will be across the border DLF to go to Russian that we should n't be under the German occupation .

Before you go any further , I want to ask you a couple more questions about Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

Yes ?

You said that you walked this park DLF and you saw the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE and people coming from the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE , did you have any contact with those people ?

When the Warsaw GHETTO POPULATED_PLACE Ghetto uprising took place in April of ' 43 , what did you see , what were people talking about on the outside NPIP ?

The Jews are burning .

The feathers were flying all over Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE , -- feathers , smoke , a smell .

We knew that the Jews are burning in the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE .

But I could n't do nothing .

I had no contact , and I would be afraid frankly to go over and to look .

I knew I would lose my life .

We were hiding away , but at the same time , this time I think already we knew and the papers were writing that Stalingrad POPULATED_PLACE has fallen .

Stalingrad POPULATED_PLACE has fallen and the Germans are receding back .

That they did n't succeed to take Moscow POPULATED_PLACE .

The Germans - when I was still in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE , the Germans had black flags .

When they lost Stalingrad POPULATED_PLACE they put out that this was the saddest day for them .

The military people were writing articles that this is the worst day for them , that they lost Stalingrad POPULATED_PLACE .

Privately everybody knew that once they lost Stalingrad POPULATED_PLACE and they started around back , that they would lose the war .

And everybody hoped that there would come a day that we will be liberated .

And you only lived with one thought in mind , to live one day longer than Hitler , and then to die .

So you had a lot of access to what the German people , or the Polish people were thinking on the other side of the wall DLF ?

Anything else you can remember in terms of their attitude ?

They did n't care whether the Ghetto POPULATED_PLACE is burning or did they talk about the camps POPULATED_PLACE or anything ?

You see , I was with that Volksdeutsche family .

They were against Polish people and they were against Jews .

I was too young I guess to go into politics with adults and I tried to avoid even to have friends .

I started to develop a young little lady and boys started to try to talk to me .

I was bowing my head and I walked away .

I was afraid to talk to them .

So , I was too afraid to talk to anybody except what I was reading in the papers .

I was very much interested in what is going on in the world , and I bought the Polish papers which I was able to read and whatever I could make out as a 14 years old and to understand what was going on .

So , you had information on the war and what was going on ?

Yes , cover to end , prior that I left Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE , the Russians were bombarding already Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

So , even that I knew that the bomb may hit , the cellar INT_SPACE that I was sitting , I was going down with the children to those bunkers INT_SPACE , you know , against the bombs , I was happy that the Russians are flying in the air DLF over Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE and they are trying to fight the Germans .

Your family had a private bunker BUILDING ?

They had bunkers INT_SPACE , 01:39 : yes .

In each house BUILDING at that time had a bunker INT_SPACE .

So , they were like sirens , everybody was running to the bunker INT_SPACE .

In my heart , I was very happy that even if I get killed that I knew it was a Russian bomb , not a German bomb .

I would think it was rather that .

How much contact did you have with your mother and your sisters while you were in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE ’ ?

Maybe twice a week , we met in the parks DLF and we talked .

We talked only on the outside NPIP about private matters about running away or something like that .

Mother always said not to give way that we should hold up and maybe in the near future the war will end and we will survive the war and this was our daily hope .

It must have been comforting that your mother was nearby ?

Of course , by myself it would be much harder .

You do n't think your family ever suspected ?

The family of me , that Iam a Jewish child ?

I think at one time she said that I have a Jewish head on my shoulders .

So , let me continue with what happened .

I saw that Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE was burning and we had to run away .

We went on the main station BUILDING and we bought tickets and we were going further .

We were traveling about eight hours by train SPATIAL_OBJ .

The older sister was already sent away to a farm DLF near Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE , so we knew where she is but where we were going to be she would n't know , but we said that we will get in touch with her .

We were traveling about eight hours .

We were already tired and exhausted and on the train SPATIAL_OBJ they said it 's not possible to in Russian the border DLF , it 's not feasible because if they catch you on the border DLF right away they will destroy us .

So , we came off the train SPATIAL_OBJ in a small village POPULATED_PLACE and we went to a family and asked for food .

They gave us food and they asked who we are .

At that time I think I told you I had an Arbeitskarte , I was no more a Jewish girl and my mother also had this document and I felt a little more secure with this document .

She would n't let us to sleep in that house BUILDING .

We had to go to a superior of this little village POPULATED_PLACE to allow us to sleep there , and we went there in person and we presented our documentation what we had and he gave us permission to remain in the village POPULATED_PLACE .

So , the first thing they said , could you work for me .

I said yes , I can remain .

I said what will be with my mother with my sister .

She said , stay a week with us and we will find her something .

So , I think I am talking about myself a lot , but this is true .

I was going for the water , in the villages POPULATED_PLACE they did n't have yet water at that time in the houses BUILDING so they had the wells DLF , and somebody was passing by and I walked over and I said do you know somebody need help .

My mother is looking for work .

She said yes , there is a man that took over like a 40 or 50 acres of land REGION and he needs some help in the kitchen INT_SPACE .

Do you think your mother would be willing to go there to take this job .

I said yes , just give me the address .

So , she gave me the address and the next day my mother and my sister went the eight kilometer , which was about four miles .

He was a single man .

He had a lot of step .

It was I do n't know how you should call it .

He was in charge of a large 01:44 : piece of land REGION , a big landowner .

When my mother went there , he hired her right away , so she packed the little stuff that she had and she went away and I was very happy .

I remained with this family for about another two , three weeks and they came an order from the Germans that from each family somebody has to go to work in the fields DLF or somebody to collect potatoes or other -- you know you take down from the fields DLF .

I do n't know how to express myself .

And I went to work and they put a sack of potatoes on my back and I fell right away , and I saw that I could n't work .

I came home BUILDING crying .

I said I can not go to work BUILDING anymore .

So , they gave me some other work , you know , in the garden DLF a little fields DLF , and I went with a cow here and there , and I said I can not stay here .

I have to go closer to where my mother is .

So , I went around four kilometers and I was looking around , and I came in .

It was a little town POPULATED_PLACE and it 's called Sokolov POPULATED_PLACE ?

Polaski .

It was n't far away from this place NPIP , and I went to a little store BUILDING and I said do you have some work for me ?

She said what can you do ?

I said I can help you with whatever you like .

I will do anything you will ask me to .

So , she was having like a little bar BUILDING , you know , and she was using me to bring in food or a 01:46 : little whiskey or something to carry into that little store BUILDING and to help to serve the tables SPATIAL_OBJ .

So , I was there , and the store BUILDING was like about two miles away from her home BUILDING .

She took me home BUILDING and she did n't pay me , but I had food and I had a bed SPATIAL_OBJ .

She was also a woman by herself and she had an adopted daughter .

She was also slaughtering pigs and making delis and she was selling that .

She took me to the market BUILDING to buy pigs and I fell right into this family and I was doing everything together .

We went together to buy those pigs for the market BUILDING and the illegal whiskey she was buying and selling and she was making a lot of money .

The whole police BUILDING station was there and I felt I am very secure there .

She also had some a cow and some other things that had to be looked after and I did all of that .

At one point , she said to me , you know you really have a Jewish head on her shoulder .

When she told me that , I almost died inside NPIP myself .

This was around December , the holidays came over and I had to look that everything I should do correctly when the holiday are there , and behave like a real Christian .

A Jewish head , what did she mean ?

I was too smart .

I was so smart that I am thinking like a 01:48 : real Jew .

So , she said this Easter you will go with me to the church BUILDING and you will do the confession in front of a priest .

When she told me that I almost died inside NPIP .

I said how will I be able to do that ?

I went to the church BUILDING .

I was hiding someplace in the corner NPIP .

I said the prayer , whatever I said , nobody was listening to me if I said correctly or not , and here I will have to stand in front of a priest and to say all those prayers , and she was standing right behind my back .

I kneeled down -- again , I brought myself the catechism , this is a religious book , and there was no electricity and I bought candles , and where I took the money from the candles I do n't recall , and at night I was learning the catechism from the beginning to the end .

And I must say I had a terrific head .

I had a good memory .

I do n't know if this was out of necessity or I was young or I was brilliant , and I knew all those prayers .

So , the holidays came closer and I prepared myself like every night and when she went to sleep I put on the candle and I was studying and I went in front of the priest and I kneeled down and I said you have to unburden yourself with all the sins that you committed during the year , and I was I think past 14 at that time , and I really was an innocent child , what could I have sinned .

You know what I told the priest ?

That I was saying bad things about my mother which was n't true , but I had nothing else to say .

He looked at me and he saw such a young face and he gave me a prayer 30 times to say I should cleanse myself with those prayers and I went to the corner of the church BUILDING and I said all the prayers , and I came out of the church BUILDING and I was very , very relieved .

Believe me , since then she never said that I had a Jewish head on my shoulders .

This was around Easter time .

I think around end of June I started to see Russian soldiers coming in , and they said that the Germans are running away already from the territories REGION that I was there , but I could n't believe it .

They were dirty , they were torn .

The uniforms that they wore they looked like they run away from concentration POPULATED_PLACE camps themselves .

It did n't look to me like military people .

I was sitting quiet but I was running over to my mother and I said you know I think the Germans are going .

We have already the Russians .

She said be quiet and sit still and do n't talk to nobody .

We have to see and wait what will go on .

Then in August I do n't know if I heard from people or papers , I saw that Lublin POPULATED_PLACE is already free .

Lublin POPULATED_PLACE is freed by the Russian people .

I went again to tell my mother this news , and she started -- I started to feel like you know she was stepping on me and I was doing a lot of chores and no matter what I did when she was killing a pig she needed maybe 50 pails of water and I had to carry it by myself and I just felt the evenings that I could n't do this any more .

She started to get very rude and I had the sense of feeling that I was already liberated in a way .

The Russians are here NPIP already why should I perform such work and she does n't deserve it .

So , | went to my mother and I told her that I 'm going to leave this lady because she became unbearable to me .

She said sit another couple of months and we 'll see what will 01:53 develop .

But I packed myself up .

I can only tell you that I had only one pair of shoes and one little underwear , my whole thing was a little package , and I took this package one day and I said to mother I arrived at mother NPIP 's place and said you can kill me here NPIP .

I am not going back to that woman .

She 's a real witch , and I do n't want to suffer any more .

My clothes started to fall apart .

You know as you grow you start to expand so I started to get holes in my clothes and she would n't buy me nothing .

There was a certain resentment and anger , so I was working only for the food .

But really the liberation and knowing that the Germans are going , I wanted to see what will be next .

And when I said to my mother that even if she 'll kill me , I 'm not going back to the woman , she had no choice .

So , she said okay you will sleep here NPIP .

The next day I walked out into the garden DLF and there were a lot of -- at this Volksdeutsch , the man that my mother worked for , he run away already .

There was no supervision over nobody , over the food that they have grown it was just like everybody lived by themselves .

I met a man , listen to that , and he was an adult , I was at the time already close to 15 , and he took me aside in the garden DLF and he said I suspect that you are a Jewish girl and your mother too , with the other sister .

I can tell you that in Lublin POPULATED_PLACE there is already the Jewish committee from America COUNTRY that they came and they established , and you are too young to live here in the villages POPULATED_PLACE and you will ruin yourselves .

Go to Lublin POPULATED_PLACE and there will be new hope for you .

I was afraid to tell my mother .

I could n't believe my ears what he told me .

I did n't know if he wants to convince me that you know that I 'm Jewish that I should confess or he really wants to help me .

So , I did n't tell my mother that this guy spoke to me .

But I told my mother that I heard that the Lublin POPULATED_PLACE there are Jews already , that they are congregating the old survivors are there , that they are running to Lublin POPULATED_PLACE .

So , she said let 's sit another couple of 01:56 : months .

Do n't talk to nobody that you are Jewish and we 'll see what will happen .

She was pulling time .

She wanted to reassure herself that we should n't be too hasty to make a step forward that we should n't get lost .

You know what I did .

Once a Russian soldier spoke to me and I asked him if he can bring me to Lublin POPULATED_PLACE and he said he 's going in that direction > I was fearless , and I said I 'll go and I 'll take a look by myself .

I went on a big truck SPATIAL_OBJ .

He did n't touch me , you know I did n't think of it that he will abuse me or rape me or something like that .

Somehow I was so innocent and I believed in the goodness of the people that they liberated me that he can not do nothing wrong to me .

I came to Lublin POPULATED_PLACE and I go on the street DLF and I looked at someone that look to me like a Jewish person and I asked him in Polish do you know where the Jewish Gemeinde is here ?

So , he asked you are you Amkho .

Amkho was Jewish code word for being Jewish .

I could n't answer him in the Jewish language because my tongue just could n't speak any more Jewish .

I told him in Polish that yes I am a Jewish girl .

That I am one of the survivors and I am looking for the Gemeinde .

When I came there , they met me there and they tried to talk to me and I told them that I have a mother left near Sokolove POPULATED_PLACE ?

Polaski , and he said that I should bring her here with my sister and they will be maybe able to give us some lodging and we will be able to start to live as Jews again .

End of Tape # 1 Tape # 2

A Peretz was a famous scholar [ writer ] or I think that was probably related with the history of Palestine COUNTRY before the war , so there was such a home BUILDING like an organization where they met .

So , you arrived in Lublin POPULATED_PLACE and who are these people that you met ?

You know when we arrived in Lublin POPULATED_PLACE , they had a place they called Dom BUILDING Peretz .

It was called Dom BUILDING Peretza , or the House BUILDING of Peretz .

People went there daily to meet other people and to hear what is going on , just to communicate and how to live and how to organize our lives .

So , my mother met there people that she knew from before the war that they had already an apartment INT_SPACE there and they recommended a small apartment INT_SPACE on Lubartovska BUILDING 18 in Lublin POPULATED_PLACE .

02:03 :

I think we 're skipping something .

If I remember when we stopped before you were there by yourself .

Your mother was n't there yet .

And also , these people you met with , were they part of some international committee , the people in charge ?

I do n't know if they were international committee , probably some .

The leaders were , but they started probably to employ people that survived or were capable or giving or lending help .

They were partisans that had survived and I think that the Russians , the military was also involved to help the Jewish people .

I told you that I arrived in Poland COUNTRY by myself , right .

I went back , and it took me maybe four weeks to convince my mother she should come with me to Lublin POPULATED_PLACE .

Finally she did .

So , she packed , not with everything , but she took a little belongings and you know what happened ?

We went on the train SPATIAL_OBJ to Lublin POPULATED_PLACE .

I went down to ask really the directions is this train SPATIAL_OBJ is going to Lublin POPULATED_PLACE , the train SPATIAL_OBJ started to go and my mother went there and I remained on the station BUILDING by myself .

So , I took the next train SPATIAL_OBJ and then I went to that Gemeinde , and I met my mother over there , and I think it was with my twin sister .

And your other sister ?

I skipped this part .

You see when we were liberated already and I ran away from that lady and I did n't want to work with her , so and we were talking about Lublin POPULATED_PLACE so my mother took my twin sister and she bought her a ticket to go to the older sister where she was in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE , and this 1s for the first time that she knew that we were alive and that she is alive and she was there and we brought her to us where we were together where my mother was when everybody was running away .

I 'm telling you there was food , plenty of everything because there was nobody to take charge so my mother was the whole housekeeper there .

So , my sister came there too , and then all of us we proceeded to Lublin POPULATED_PLACE .

02:06 :

When you got Lublin POPULATED_PLACE , you found an apartment INT_SPACE ?

Somebody recommended my mother found friends there from the prewar from a nearby town POPULATED_PLACE that they knew her that they already had an apartment INT_SPACE and they recommended .

It was a two or three room apartment INT_SPACE , but you know they , the committee , put in maybe ten people into it .

There were four girls in one room INT_SPACE and the other ones were in the other place NPIP , but it was fine as long as there was a floor INT_SPACE to put our heads , we were happy .

Who were alot of these other Jewish people who were in this area REGION what were they like ?

Where had they been ?

There were a lot from the woods ENV_FEATURES .

They came out from the woods ENV_FEATURES , the partisans , a lot of them they came out and also from hiding .

My step father , that my mother married in 1945 he was in Sobibor POPULATED_PLACE , in the uprising of the Sobibor POPULATED_PLACE [ camp POPULATED_PLACE ] .

You probably heard about it .

He was one of the members that they tried to get rid of the Germans at that time and run away , but unfortunately about 600 people remained the people because the top people that were the guards , the top of the building BUILDING , they could n't reach them and they had the ammunition they were shooting from there all around .

So , they almost killed all the 600 Jews .

I think after the war from the 600 that were supposed to be liberated maybe 30 survived .

Were there any people there from Maidanek POPULATED_PLACE ?

At that time , maybe not yet , not yet .

You know when I came to Lublin POPULATED_PLACE basically the people were there that survived the Polish REGION territory .

The partisans were hidden by the peasants or wherever .

This was in 1944 , but in 1945 when the concentration POPULATED_PLACE camps were liberated , I started to see those people from the concentration POPULATED_PLACE camps , those skeletons I started to see , and I just could n't believe it that something like this exists because I was never exposed to something like that .

Had n't you had any idea what was going on in other parts when you were in hiding ?

Did you know anything about what was happening to the Jews ?

No , I did n't know about the concentration POPULATED_PLACE camps at all .

I knew they were being killed , but how and what and I could n't perceive in my head you know to understand that something like this existed .

In fact , in 1983 I was in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE and this was for the opening of the synagogue BUILDING in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE .

There was a lot of Jews coming from all over the world and I went just to be there as a survivor -- I lost my thought -- and I went for the first time they took us to Oswiecim POPULATED_PLACE , and they took us to Treblinka POPULATED_PLACE , and all those things .

This 1s the first time that I had ever seen something like that .

I have seen those glasses , the luggage SPATIAL_OBJ and the shoes and all those clothes over there and the hair what I have seen .

I almost fainted .

I have never seen while I was living in Poland COUNTRY in the Polish REGION territory I was fortunate enough not to be exposed to those things .

So , I 'll let you continue .

We 're in Lublin POPULATED_PLACE , you found a place with some other people .

What was that like ?

Well , we started to live rather well and together with a family .

We were able I do n't know how we got our food .

I think we got the help from that Jewish Gemeinde , and also my mother remarried in 1945 a man that she knew from before the war .

He was a landowner and he sold some of his land REGION and he started wheeling and dealing and he already was making business and there was n't any lack of food or anything 1n the house BUILDING in 1944 .

Around February 1945 I started to inquire about school BUILDING .

I went to the sixth grade in February and by June I had a certificate that I finished six classes of elementary BUILDING school .

With that in the fall I started to go to a higher education , a gymnasium BUILDING .

My mother wanted that we should go to a gymnasium BUILDING .

So , I needed seven classes of public BUILDING school to enter the second -- the second class of gymnasium BUILDING and I did n't have this so I went to the Jewish Gemeinde and they gave me a paper that I finished seven classes .

It was n't real , but somehow I wanted just to be there for a higher education .

But you know I was sitting and when they started to teach algebra and history and geography which was forbidden even in that time at Poland COUNTRY when I was in the fourth grade , I did n't have the slightest idea of what a map was looking and I did n't know what algebra meant .

I thought I was such a brilliant girl and all of a sudden I am standing in front of a professor and he 's talking to me and explaining and I just could n't follow .

So , I went home BUILDING crying and I said I am not going to school BUILDING .

I am not prepared .

I 'm not going to be a dummy there .

She was a clever woman and she said we 'll give you some help and she brought in help , tutors and I needed help in mathematics , this was a high education in mathematics already .

Of course in English , my English was not on level and other areas REGION .

So , for three months the tutors came in and helped me to the level that I was supposed to be , and after three months I had the exam in the school BUILDING and I achieved the highest report card .

This was Jewish BUILDING school ?

No , this was a general gymnasium BUILDING .

But you know what happened later ?

The first month they selected me I should be the president of the class .

The second month somehow they got to know that I was a Jewish girl , they took me away my position .

They did n't like that and on top of it all we used to where a uniform , black uniforms and white collars and on the back they wrote you are a dirty Jewish girl .

This was after the liberation in 1945 or maybe beginning of 1946 .

In 1946 I do n't know if you 02:15 remember a lot of Jews were returning from Russia COUNTRY that run away from Poland COUNTRY to Russia COUNTRY and then they came back home BUILDING and those were the ones that were traveling by trains SPATIAL_OBJ they were pulled down .

There were two parties in Poland COUNTRY at that time .

It was Army of Krajowa ( AK ) and it was the communist the Army of KKR was against the communist and the Jews went with KKR .

The working together against the German government and because of that the AK which was the army which was against the Jews , and they were pulling down , in 1946 they were pulling down the Jews from the trains SPATIAL_OBJ and killing them .

So , they started to get againt such anti semitism so some tried to run away , and at that time the displaced POPULATED_PLACE camps opened in Germany COUNTRY already and everybody was telling us that if you go to Germany COUNTRY to displaced POPULATED_PLACE camps , you 'll be able to immigrate to the United COUNTRY States .

This was everybody 's dream , to run away to a free country COUNTRY not to be persecuted any more .

So , one day I came back from school BUILDING .

This was again around Easter holidays and we had the Shochet , do you know Shochet , kill chickens for the holidays for the Jews to have kosher meat .

I come from school BUILDING as a liberated , feeling liberated after such a war , you know surviving Hitler and all of a sudden in the hallways INT_SPACE they are talking about the Jews killed a Polish child and there were about 200 people standing in that hall INT_SPACE entering that house BUILDING where I was living .

When I heard that I said it 's time to leave Poland COUNTRY .

No more Poland COUNTRY .

I have to get away from there .

Of course I knew already my husband , my future husband .

I was going out with that young man .

I think my older sister got engaged also to a man that he came from Russia COUNTRY with the Sikorski Army .

Maybe you know about this that there was 02:18 : Sikorsrki Army .

He came back from Russia COUNTRY and he was in uniform as a military man and she got engaged to him and she left in February in 1946 to Germany COUNTRY to West POPULATED_PLACE Berlin , and I wanted also to go .

I did n't want to stay in Poland COUNTRY especially after this incident when I came from school BUILDING and they said that the Jews killed a Polish child for Matza .

So , I made my business and I made up at that time to leave .

Either my mother will allow me or not allow me to go , so I told my mother and she said of course I can not go .

I was only 17 .

Yes I was 17 and she said you will go with that young man ?

I said yes I will go with that man .

She said you are not married , you can not go .

So , I said so I 'll marry him and then I 'll go .

So , she called up a couple of people witnesses and they put some liquor on the table SPATIAL_OBJ and some cookies and candies and this was the whole wedding and the same night I went away to Germany COUNTRY .

Not to Germany COUNTRY , I went to Breslau POPULATED_PLACE and I was there a couple of months with my husband .

I married him already , and I became pregnant and the Jewish organization , the underground organization from Israel COUNTRY started to work to bring out as many Jews from Poland COUNTRY as they could .

I think they approached us and we said yes and then one day they picked us up in the truck SPATIAL_OBJ and we were crossing the Czechoslovakian DLF border to Austria COUNTRY and as I said I was pregnant already .

I was there six weeks and such a it was like a military BUILDING barracks .

This was Eichstadt POPULATED_PLACE near Munich POPULATED_PLACE , and I was there until my son was born .

This was from November in 1946 until May in 1947 , so I was in that Eichstadt POPULATED_PLACE camp , and my sister went from Berlin POPULATED_PLACE she went into Salsheim POPULATED_PLACE .

They brought her into Salsheim POPULATED_PLACE near Frankfurt POPULATED_PLACE am Main .

There was also a DP POPULATED_PLACE camp .

Let me just ask you about the first camp POPULATED_PLACE .

What were the living conditions like ?

It was terrible .

Maybe ten women had to cook on the one little stove SPATIAL_OBJ .

There was no running water .

When I gave birth , I went to a military BUILDING hospital and of course they said a child is having a child and they gave me a military blanket and what kind of a dish something you know that it looked like I should be able to bathe the child , and I went back to this barrack BUILDING .

The barrack BUILDING was divided with pieces of wood .

When this wood dried out everybody was looking into the other , like you know to the bedrooms INT_SPACE .

It was terrible , the living conditions were terrible .

They were like animals .

Those people that came out from the concentration POPULATED_PLACE camps they behaved like animals .

They grabbed away everything that you had .

They had no manners .

They were so ... you know I lived through certain fear but I had a mother to guide me and I did n't see those barbaric things .

They came out and they were literally stepping over dead bodies , so they did n't care if I was standing in the line DLF for my milk or something or the portions to get my food so they pushed me and I was nine months pregnant or something like that .

It was really unbearable .

I was rather depressed because I started to look back when I was with my mother and I was really -- I was with other people that they knew me and they treated me very well as a human being .

Here in the displaced POPULATED_PLACE camp I started to feel very 02:23 : very low , very depressed .

Also , I missed home BUILDING , you know .

I left my twin sister and being in a strange place NPIP in a strange country COUNTRY and I did n't know what my future was holding for me and having a small child .

There was no diapers , there was no food for the baby , very little .

I had to stand in line DLF for every piece of food that I was getting .

So , it was very bad .

This camp POPULATED_PLACE was run by the U.S. military ?

I think so .

It was the -- the barracks BUILDING were U.S. military .

I think it was also run by the UNRRA BUILDING .

The UNRRA BUILDING was running it .

Did you befriend any of these people from the camps POPULATED_PLACE ?

Some of them I befriended but my aim was to go to my sister where she was in Saltzheim POPULATED_PLACE and she gave birth also to a child at that time and we wanted to be together so they saw to it that I should have a room INT_SPACE .

It was a little house BUILDING like in each house BUILDING was a family so I came there .

We were there in Salzheim POPULATED_PLACE about seven months and they discontinued this displaced -- the DP POPULATED_PLACE camp .

What was it like up there ?

We lived rather well .

We did n't have good facilities , like one room INT_SPACE was for every family .

It was a little house BUILDING we took away from the Germans -- I do n't know if they took away or the Germans left , what facilities we had one room INT_SPACE per family .

There was also no water , no running water .

I think there was electricity , but in general it was not bad .

We did n't have to pay rent and we had portions of food .

We got some clothes , so as young people I think we accepted this is not bad at all , but let 's wait until we get to the United COUNTRY States .

Was your husband working there or anything ?

Were there activities ?

Were there cultural things ?

Did they start training ?

They started to train some of the young people , you know like to teach them how to sew and other trades .

I think they brought in the old to teach some trade to the people , but I did n't because I had a small child .

My husband I think he was doing some dealing and wheeling , like buying a few pounds of coffee and selling and exchanging for some other food .

This was his activities .

What about the Jewish religion ?

Did you observe any of the holidays or the Sabbath or anything like that ?

None of that ?

This was far away .

I do n't recall even in Frankfurt POPULATED_PLACE when we arrived already everybody was a little bit on their feet and they started to live a more normal life that we started to go to synagogues BUILDING .

I do n't recall it no .

I was living among the Germans .

I started to speak fluently German and by the end , the last eight months I even hired help for my child because I really did n't know if I was raising him properly or not .

I did what nature told me to do , and when my husband started to deal a little more and he was selling those foods and we had a little more money , I hired -- she was a nurse .

Actually she was a nurse .

And at that time , I started to breath a little easier .

Your mother was still where NPIP ?

My mother came already .

She left in 1948 and she came to the United COUNTRY States and she was held over in Ellis POPULATED_PLACE Island .

Supposedly she did n't know that those papers were illegal and they wanted them to return to go back to Poland COUNTRY or there was at that time there was a quota to go to Cuba COUNTRY .

My mother had a brother here and her whole hope was to come here to see her brother but prior to her arrival he died .

So , she was so disappointed that she wanted to go back to Poland COUNTRY , and the brother 's children they tried to help her .

They hired an attorney and she was sitting on Ellis POPULATED_PLACE Island for six weeks and she made a decision not to stay in the United COUNTRY States and not to go back to Poland COUNTRY but to go to Cuba COUNTRY .

Actually , the attorneys I think advised her to go to Cuba COUNTRY , that she will stay for a short time .

I think it was the attorney 's decision that they should have them in Cuba COUNTRY and from Cuba COUNTRY they will be able to come to the United COUNTRY States in a very short time , but it took them two years .

When they arrived in Cuba COUNTRY the living condition was also very , very poor where in Poland COUNTRY right after the war when my mother remarried that Mr. Mermelstein ( ? ) ,

he came from a very wealthy family and he sold off some land REGION so he considered himself a wealthy guy , and they lived rather well .

In Cuba COUNTRY they were n't allowed to work .

Immigrants were n't allowed to work and my mother was so proud that there were kitchens INT_SPACE that you could eat free food , so she went a couple times and when she got to know that this was charity she was starving to death and she would n't go .

She was a very proud woman .

02:30

What was your situation ?

How long did you stay in the Frankfurt POPULATED_PLACE area and how difficult was it for you to come over here ?

Well , we stayed there until we had the notices to come to the consulate BUILDING and prepare ourselves for the immigration to the United COUNTRY States .

I immigrated to the United COUNTRY States .

Our arrival was May 9 in 1950 .

I want to back up a little bit because you spent several years pretending you were n't Jewish .

And you had to learn the catholic prayers but I 'm sure there were other things that you had to do to make sure you were n't caught .

That I was n't caught , I do n't recall what other things I could do except to go to the church BUILDING and to act as a Christian , and you almost become a Christian .

You become -- you do n't feel Jewish after a while , except mentally that I felt that I am Jewish , that I was born Jewish .

But in my speech the knowledge of the Polish language was typical of a Polish little girl .

There were moments I 'm sure that I forgot that I am a Jewish girl .

Were there things that you had to do so you would n't give yourself a way .

Were there ways you need to act or do things a certain way ?

I was afraid to get close to a friend .

I remember a young boy started to smile at me for instance , and he wanted just to talk to me and I run away from him .

I was running away from everybody that wanted to be close to me except my mother and my sisters .

I was afraid to be close .

I should n't talk to them .

I should n't give away myself .

So , I was always on the guard .

Were there any customs that were different for catholics than Jews that you had to pay attention to , any lifestyle things ?

Life styles , I could n't eat for instance a meal like pig meat , how you call it , pork , and the first time they gave me pork 02:33 with potatoes I could n't tell them that I do n't eat them , and I was hungry .

But when I ate it , I threw it up and I pretended to be ill at the time .

I did n't tell them that I threw it up because it was pork .

So , those were the things that in the beginning that it was n't acceptable for me , but I had to hide my feelings , how I feel and not to give myself away .

Was it important that you worked , you were just a kid basically ?

I was a kid .

It was important , of course it helped me mentally to be with somebody , but there was a rule in Poland COUNTRY at that time that the Jewish family can not live together .

This was a rule that came out I believe in late 1941 that the Jewish family can not -- they started to disperse and there was a time that you could stay with other Polish people but not as a family together .

So , to work for somebody was a basic survival for food and lodging BUILDING .

This is the only way that I could survive .

I could n't stay with my mother .

I could n't have my own room INT_SPACE and I was n't able to take care of myself .

I had to be with another family to -- this was only through my work and ability whatever I could do to help those families this capacity of course I was n't paid much , almost nothing .

When they gave me a piece of clothes , I was very grateful .

But you could n't have stayed together as a Polish family ?

No , no this was too dangerous .

And where would my mother get the income ?

We lost our house BUILDING , the piece of land REGION -- we had about three acres of land REGION .

We had like a grocery BUILDING store and we had milk , you know we lost all of that .

This was taken away from us .

So , what were the other resources to survive , then to work or stay with other families .

Did you ever have a hiding place of something that in case you were caught you would go to ?

Prior that I arrived in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE and we went on that journey to be caught as a Polish woman and to go into the Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE to travel to Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE we were hidden in barns BUILDING , in barns BUILDING the people 02:36 knew that we were there .

They brought us the food at night .

You could n't go to the toilet SPATIAL_OBJ the whole day .

You had to wait until 1 t got dark .

So , this was the only times that we were hidden .

Each time a couple of weeks with another family and this was going on for like a year .

This was the most painful experience because the whole day you had to be hiding .

Only at night could you be free to go to the bathroom INT_SPACE or something , whatever was necessary things to do .

But in Warsaw POPULATED_PLACE , you did n't have an alternative plan or a hiding NPIP place or something ?

Did you know or were you aware of other Jewish people who were hiding out in the Polish side of Russia COUNTRY ?

No , and frankly I did n't want to know .

I was afraid .

You know everybody became for themselves .

I was concerned about my mother and my sisters but I was afraid to get in touch if somebody even looked like Jewish .

Not because I was hating the Jews , this was because of fear and -- of deep fear and suffering and not to be exposed to unpleasant things .

In other words , if somebody was to identify me with a friend that is Jewish , they would automatically say why am I siding with the Jewish girl .

So , if I am siding with a Jewish girl , I am Jewish also and my life was threatened .

I was very much aware that I should n't get close to nobody .

And you learned about the catholic religion largely on your own ?

02:38 :

On my own , and just by looking the way others did .

How the children behaved , how the children of the people that I worked behaved , and I followed them or maybe I should use the word emulated them with great intensity .

Did you resent being Jewish ?

If I resented being Jewish , I do n't know if I had the ability at that time to understand why I was born Jewish , but there were moments when I saw a cat or a dog and they were walking around freely , I envied them .

I really envied them .

I said why could n't I be a cat .

Why could n't I be a dog .

I should be able to move , but if I was angry with myself that I was born Jewish , I do n't think that I understood at that time that this was part of history that I was born into .

I do n't think that I could think rationally like that like I look back now at this .

That this was the period of history that it 's unfortunate for me that I had to be born at this time .

But you would have felt safer if you were born catholic ?

Of course .

So , you must have wished that you were truly catholic girl ?

You know , when I was running at night from one place NPIP to another , and I saw those lights in the homes BUILDING and sometimes I heard laughter or talking in a normal way , family to family , I was so envious that those people lived normal and I run like a beaten up dog with constant fear with constant such heaviness in my head .

How will I survive the next day or the next minute .

I was walking one night through the fields DLF to another family to convey something , and they stopped me .

This was the police and they asked me immediately what is my name .

I told them Bernislava Bershenska and somehow they let me go .

I was at that time afraid that this would be it .

You know assume that I caught myself in such moments , I assumed that I will die very soon .

When you got to Lublin POPULATED_PLACE and you could be open about who you were , what did that feel like ?

I think we were very happy that our wish came true , that we finally survived Hitler .

You can not imagine the wish of young and old that they wished to survive only one day after Hitler is gone and I can die in peace .

This was the children spoke like that , the adults spoke like that and this was a sense of freedom .

A sense of freedom but also it brought our problems how to go on , what to do with this freedom .

How our lives should continue .

What will be next .

How to reconstruct a life .

The people were basically they were happy .

They were concentrating with each other and we all became survivors as a matter of fact we became like a family .

They were all practically -- most of them they were young because old people could n't survive and children could n't survive .

So , the young people they tried to get acquainted with one another to do things for one another to care for another .

As a matter of fact , a girl knew a boy three weeks , this already was a long time .

Let 's get married .

Everybody was seeking somebody to be close to , to be together , to function as a human being again .

A lot of people were looking for the families and they could n't find .

Like my husband arrived with his brother , he survived in Russia COUNTRY and he went to his hometown POPULATED_PLACE and he saw nothing .

He was very disappointed .

He had I think three or four brothers .

Nobody was alive .

Not a sign of any life in his hometown POPULATED_PLACE , so he came to Lublin POPULATED_PLACE at that time also .

Was it easy to get close to people ?

To our own survivors , yes , but not to others .

As a matter of fact , to this day I do n't know if you know about this but all our survivors they stick together .
